The Community model for the distinguishing sign of the Member State licensing of vehicles and trailers in internal Community traffic, let us call it the European nationality plate, is long overdue. Such a measure directly helps to include and raise the awareness of the citizens of the Union in the creation of an area without internal borders and to form and establish a feeling of European identity, while contributing indirectly to n increase in road traffic safety. In particular, the demand that the proposed Community sign must be located both at the front and at the back on the left beside the registration plate will be an advantage for the police and other administrative and judicial bodies.

Although on behalf of the Group of the European People"s Party I completely support Mr Le Rachinel"s report and thank him for his work, it seems to me personally that the Commission"s proposal for a regulation is not completely logical. Let us just consider: in a few weeks the third phase of European economic and monetary union begins, which will lead to a domestic market, the formal external appearance of which will be the single currency. What a magnificent achievement, proving our great farsightedness! With the distinguishing sign for vehicles and trailers the Europeans are failing to achieve logical standardization in the form of a common, standard design principle. Thus, with reference to the principle of subsidiarity, the EU Member States are obliged in fact to recognize the proposed Community model, but the validity of existing nationality plates remains completely unrestricted and continues to exist, independent of the Community model.

There is not even a reference to the fact that in the Member States the Community model should preferably be used. In view of this fact, I could even understand if citizens from third countries were doubtful of the ability and/or seriousness of the efforts of EU to build a political union.

For the vehicle owners of the Member States who have already accepted, on a compulsory or voluntary basis, the use of the Community model – it is of course not a new invention –, the present proposal for a regulation takes up a long‐standing desire for legal certainty and is recognition – let us call it personal – of the costs they often willingly incurred when buying this combined vehicle registration plate.

For me, too, it is desirable that third countries, above all the countries of the European Economic Area but also the associated countries of central and eastern Europe give legally binding recognition to the Community model. I recommend that we accept this report.

  Schierhuber (PPE). – (DE) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like briefly to express an opinion on Mr Le Rachinel"s report on the transport of dangerous goods by road. One of the Union"s aims is the completion of the single market. We should do everything we can to guarantee its successful operation by implementing suitable measures. In this sense the free passage of vehicles transporting dangerous goods should be possible. Above all, I believe it is very appropriate to harmonize design features and technical specifications, for example on brake fittings, speed limitations or electrical equipment, to guarantee free passage within the Community.

The creation of a European type‐approval system will help ensure that in future no Member State will be able, on grounds which relate to design features, to prohibit a vehicle manufacturer from offering it for sale, or to refuse its approval or use. The Member States should thus be obliged to produce the necessary legal and administrative regulations within 12 months of the publication of this directive.

  Ferber (PPE). – (DE) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, at this late hour we are once again discussing transport policy questions. Let me make just two short remarks. Firstly, I would like to look at the issue of transportable pressure equipment which unfortunately has figured too briefly in this joint debate. This is a very important matter, not only from a technical viewpoint – although to me as an engineer it appears thoroughly interesting, ‐ but it also as regards the question of safety of everything which travels on our roads. It concerns the question of regular monitoring and the capability to carry out this monitoring and I think that here it is the rapporteur, whom I would like to thank sincerely, who has succeeded in presenting a balanced report. I can only ask the Commission to listen carefully to Parliament.

Secondly, I would like to consider the distinguishing sign of the Member State of registration, that is, the national registration plate. I consider that, too, to be an important proposal and Mr Koch referred to the problems which we still face. Here at last we have a regulation with which we can bring Europe to life. As well as the standard driving licence, which has already been decided on, it is a further symbol to make Europe come to life. It is a citizen‐friendly decision which makes administration simpler. I would just like to ask you, Commissioner, to take this up perhaps in negotiations with Switzerland too, because it is not sensible or logical to introduce it throughout Europe, and have it recognized in the European Economic Area, and in the associated states, while right in the middle of Europe we have an Island of the Blissful, where we still have to have our stickers. I ask that you take this up in the negotiations.

  Kinnock, Neil, Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to begin by thanking Mr Le Rachinel for his two reports, firstly on the proposal relating to the type‐approval of motor vehicles and trailers intended for the transport of dangerous goods by road and, secondly, on the distinguishing sign for vehicles.

On the first report, I am pleased to say that the Commission accepts Mr Le Rachinel's single amendment, since the additional wording he suggests on Article 6 provides the correct legal term for the date of implementation and does not in any way contradict or change the intention of the Commission proposal.

This legislation, as the House will know, is an important step towards harmonization of the laws of Member States on typeapproval procedures relating to vehicles carrying dangerous goods. I am therefore grateful for the constructive approach taken by the rapporteur and his colleagues. Colleagues, indeed, like Mr Morris who, in an erudite and convincing speech, would not only have demolished any doubts at all about the transport of dangerous goods but probably have persuaded everyone that Wales should have its very own distinctive number plate. That would, of course, be permissible, as we see evidenced by the fact that in the Republic of Ireland the name of the region is given on the numberplate in Erse and in Germany the Land badge is also shown conventionally on the numberplates. So I am looking forward to seeing a draig goch, the red dragon, on Mr Morris' numberplate. I am sure that would be a very popular step. Not that I would dream of intervening in subsidiarity to advocate it publicly.

Mr Le Rachinel's second report concerns numberplates. Because of press misreporting, which has on occasion misinformed public opinion on the issue of vehicle numberplates and distinguishing signs, I think it wise to begin my short response to this very constructive report by saying what the proposal does not mean. Firstly, it does not have any suggestion that Member States must provide numberplates which incorporate the symbol of the European Union. Secondly, it does not have any suggestion that all vehicles must show the symbol of the country of registration.

I specify this because Mr Jarzembowski will I know be interested to be informed that a couple of years ago the Daily Mail – not a newspaper that I customarily buy – incredibly printed a front‐page story about me going to impose Euro‐numberplates on all unsuspecting citizens of the Union. The story was so inaccurate, misleading and mischievous, that I sued the Daily Mail and, I am happy to say, successfully. I hope that they will record, with precision, what this proposal does and does not do.

The aim of the proposal is simply to ensure that where the rear numberplate on a vehicle shows the distinguishing sign of the Member State of registration, on the background of the symbol of the Community, the distinguishing sign is recognized by the other Member States as a valid identification of the country of registration, without further need for the vehicle to show any other sign. That includes the elliptic sticker, the rugby‐ball‐shaped sticker specified by the Vienna Convention. It may be, of course, as far as Mr Morris is concerned, that shape of sticker would do for Wales, but I understand that too.

I know that Members of this House understand that and I would like, therefore, to respond to the amendments tabled by the Committee on Transport and Tourism. First, we welcome Amendment No 2 and the first part of Amendment No 3, which extends the coverage of the regulation to trailers. We can also accept the second part of Amendment No 3, which refers to the position of the distinguishing sign on the left‐hand side of the numberplate. In addition, we can accept in principle the last part of Amendment No 3 that refers to other official signs. But we believe that the wording and the purpose of the recognition, which is to identify the state of registration of the vehicle, could be more specific.

The Commission cannot accept Amendment No 1, which is intended to introduce a requirement to affix the distinguishing sign of registration on the left‐hand side of the plate. However, the amendment actually changes the legal term distinguishing registration signs, which simply means the official abbreviation used to denote the Member State. The term itself and the definition are consistent with the Vienna Convention, which is as it should be.

As in the case of the Convention, the size, shape and location of the distinguishing registration sign are specified in the Annex, although that provision is now also covered by the second part of Amendment No 3, which, as I said to the House, we have accepted.

Amendments Nos 4 to 7 have been tabled by Mr Simpson with the purpose of sanctioning or regularizing the practice of using stickers in the form of the European symbol containing the abbreviation of the country of origin. I have to say that Mr Watts did a job of which any salesman would be immensely proud in the course of the debate tonight. As a consequence, I have some sympathy for the idea.

However, I have to tell the House that these amendments do not meet the need to lay down the technical specifications with sufficient detail to achieve mutual recognition. Well I can always mutually recognize Mr Jarzembowski even if I cannot hear precisely what he is saying! Our proposal makes mutual recognition possible precisely because the sign is issued under the control of the national authorities as part of an official numberplate, and that would clearly not be the case for the separate sticker.

The eighth and final amendment by Mr Cornelissen is unnecessary since the regulation, once adopted, will be automatically applicable in the European Economic Area. Incidentally, I think history is being made. It is ten past eleven on a night in Strasbourg. We are having a transport debate and Mr Cornelissen is not actually here. This must be the first time in history and I am sure there is a very good reason for it.

I now turn to the third report and I would like to thank Mr Camisón for the time and effort that he spent on this complex technical proposal related to safety in the movement of transportable pressure equipment. As the House will know, by adopting Directives 94/55 and 96/49, the Council has already ensured a high level of safety in the movement of transportable equipment by defining common rules on design, materials, filling and periodic testing of such equipment. However, one further demand needs to be met.

The current situation is that transportable pressure equipment, for instance gas cylinders, moved from one Member State to another and then used cannot be refilled in the receiving Member State and then transported back to the first Member State without being retested, inspected and approved in the receiving country. This threatens the very existence of the single market and so obviously has to be changed. In the absence of mutual recognition of the conformity procedures and of markings of the inspection bodies in different Member States, these conditions will continue. The proposal before the House therefore seeks to rectify that. A further effect of this proposal is to ensure free circulation of transportable pressure equipment in the internal market, a facility which is not possible now because Directive 97/23 on pressure equipment excludes transportable pressure equipment from the scope.

Since Amendments Nos 4, 6, 7, 11, 12 and 19 are consistent with the aims of the proposal, the Commission is able to accept them and, as a consequence of accepting Amendments Nos 6 and 19, the Commission is able to accept Amendments Nos 10 and 20 in so far as they relate to the date.

When I conclude my time in the Commission, I can always get a job as the person who announces the lottery results on BBC television on Saturday nights. I have been training for that for some time. Señor Camisón's report provides me with the unique rehearsal in this number reading skill.

Amendment No 9 deletes Type C inspection bodies and there are related editorial changes in Amendments Nos 5, 8, 10, 11, 13, 15, 17, 18, 20, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27 and 28. They can all be accepted by the Commission if the definition of Type B inspection bodies is modified. We will therefore frame our revised proposal accordingly. And people say that DG VII functionaries do not earn their money! The other amendments, however, are not acceptable. Amendment No 1 is rejected since that ‚whereas’ clause is limited to the main objective of the proposal: transport safety. Amendments Nos 2 and 3 are primarily editorial changes but they are rejected because the original text is more accurate. Amendment No 14 is rejected because the limitation solely to existing Type B inspection bodies is too restrictive and would prevent new Type B inspection bodies from entering the market. Amendment Nos 16 and 20 are rejected since the Commission considers that frequency of controls upon relevant bodies and the details rightly fall under the competence of the Member States. Amendment No 22 is also rejected because it would not allow the same undertaking to be engaged in maintenance and periodic inspection and is therefore, in the view of the Commission, too restrictive.

As I said at the outset, this is a technical proposal which is nevertheless a further contribution to safety in transport and I am grateful for the fact that it has the support of the rapporteur, Señor Camisón, and indeed of the House. Naturally I am pleased to note that the large number of amendments manifests the attention to detail that the proposal has received from the Transport Committee rather than any real differences of substance between European Parliament and the Commission on the issue. Dealing with three different proposals in one debate is obviously not easy and this is even more true when the proposals and the discussion are particularly technical. I know, however, that the House is well able to cope with such situations, apparently better than the Commission, and I look forward to progress on all three measures now before the Parliament. I must say that history is being broken for the second time in the course of this debate. Not only is Mr Cornelissen not here but I have managed, having been given 15 minutes of the Parliament's precious time, to finish in 13 minutes and 58 seconds.

  Ferber (PPE). – (DE) Mr President, Mr Commissioner, I did not intend to spoil your future as announcer of the lottery numbers on the BBC, but you also, of course, have a past as a parliamentarian, and I had asked a question which certainly did not come up in your speech, that is, the question of how this nationality plate will be treated in Switzerland. I think it is in fact an important point if we introduce it in the European Economic Area but not in Switzerland. Is the Commission considering the possibility of finding a standard regulation in Europe which includes the Swiss authorities?

  Kinnock, Neil, Member of the Commission. – I am grateful to the honourable Member. I must say that some of my friends say that I am quite gifted in some respects, but I am not yet gifted enough to be able to read what is not written. Consequently, since the Swiss references are not part of this report, I am sure that the honourable Member, who is very understanding, will comprehend why I have not made the response.

In addition, whilst I take full account of the difficulties that can be caused because Switzerland takes a different view, I am not anxious to enter any new material in the negotiations on land transport with Switzerland which we have just concluded very satisfactorily for the Union. I will discuss it very readily with him under other circumstances.

  Jarzembowski (PPE). – (DE) It astonishes me, Commissioner, that you do not have a simple answer for a simple question, for normally you have an answer for everything, prepared or otherwise. I assume that you will follow up the question asked by Mr Ferber. In my opinion, as a stimulus we could say that we would perhaps be prepared, in exchange for recognizing this distinguishing plate, to fix the transit fee through Switzerland at 236 Swiss Francs. But maybe it would be better to discuss this over a whiskey!

  Kinnock, Neil, Member of the Commission. – First of all, I am aware that Switzerland is party to the Geneva and Vienna Conventions, so there is some reassurance there. I am also, as a special concession to Mr Jarzembowski, prepared to call the Swiss Transport Minister and recommend that in order that Mr Jarzembowski can wear any plates that he likes, he do so for the small consideration of paying double the Swiss vignette in order to pass through the country. Maybe it is a privilege he would not want to take advantage of. I certainly will see Mr Ferber on the specific issue that he raised.

  Camisón Asensio (PPE), rapporteur. – (ES) Mr President, I would not like to conclude this debate without offering my hearty congratulations to the Commissioner for his marvellous ability to trivialize this topic. Indeed, I have to put on record here that his frivolity contrasts greatly with the seriousness and concern which many sectors of European industry display, and it should go on record that this marked contrast has caught my attention.

  Kinnock, Neil, Member of the Commission. – If the honourable Member cannot tell the difference between passing amusement at some of the text that I am obliged to read out to this House, and trivializing a proposal, then his wisdom is considerably less than his years.

  President . – The debate is closed.

The vote will take place tomorrow at 12.00 noon.

(The sitting was closed at 11.20 p.m.)


ANNEXES

Annex I – Formal sitting

 

IN THE CHAIR: GIL‐ROBLES GIL‐DELGADO
President

(The sitting was opened at 12 noon)

Address by Mr Jorge Sampaio, President of the Portuguese Republic

 

  President . – Mr President, it is an honour for me to welcome you to the European Parliament. It is not only an honour, but also a source of personal and political satisfaction.

Firstly, it is a source of personal satisfaction because of your human and political qualities. It is never easy to fight for democratic values in an authoritarian context, as you have done. Nor is it easy to defend the supremacy of civilian power over military power. Your entire political career, as a member of parliament for over twenty years, as a minister, and as mayor of Lisbon, denotes an unwavering commitment to the democratic values that have permitted the European Union today to become the world"s largest democratic territory.

You are aware of the nature of my own links with Portugal. That is why it is particularly gratifying to me that the President of the Republic of Portugal should be the first Head of State that we welcome to a plenary session following my election as President. Ladies and gentlemen, President Jorge Sampaio"s presence here should also constitute a source of political satisfaction. The hurly‐burly of European debate with the, sometimes simplistic, manifestations of nationalism that it occasionally involves, at times prevents us from perceiving what is most important.

Portugal is an example of how a country with an age‐old culture has resumed its full role in Europe under difficult circumstances to do with an exceptionally rapid decolonization process and the consolidation of its democracy.

Portugal has done as it should, as the founding fathers prescribed, seeking its individual interest in the common interest. At this time, when the cohesion process is beginning, on the threshold of the introduction of the single currency and the ratification of the Treaty of Amsterdam, events which will have a decisive influence on Europe"s place during the next century, Portugal represents an example that should not be overlooked. Mr President, you, who symbolize these values, have the floor.

(Applause)

  Sampaio, Jorge, President of the Portuguese Republic. – (PT) Mr President, allow me to begin by greeting you with the greatest admiration and personal esteem, and thanking you for addressing me in my own language. This bears witness to your talents, and also to your own career because, had it not been for the struggle against dictatorships, today you might perhaps not speak Portuguese as well as you do. Allow me therefore, Mr President, to greet you personally and in your capacity as representative of the House.

Ladies and gentlemen, I am privileged to have this opportunity to address the European Parliament, this exemplary institution which in a unique manner represents the essential nature of the European Union as a democratic community.

May I thank you for this opportunity which is an honour to me and to the country which I represent. I would like, first and foremost, to greet the Members of this Parliament, who are the legitimate representatives of the community of nations committed to pursuing a unique project.

Naturally, I extend this greeting on behalf of the members of the Portuguese Government and of the representatives of all the parties which hold seats in the Portuguese Parliament who are accompanying me on this visit.

Allow me to make a special mention of the Portuguese Members, and all the Portuguese officials working in this Parliament, and to express my gratitude to them for the important work they are conducting in these bodies, in the pursuit of European ideals.

Dyed‐in‐the‐wool Euro‐enthusiast that I am, and also as a former member of parliament, this meeting with you, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, is particularly significant. May I also, Mr President, greet the President of the European Commission and the Commissioners present.

Ladies and gentlemen, in meeting the challenges inherent in the construction of the European Union, this Parliament will always occupy a central position in the discussion of ideas and in defining the proposals that will shape our collective future. I therefore consider this to be the most appropriate place for carrying out an evaluation of the state of the European Union, as a new phase is about to begin in the integration process, and for sharing with you our own views regarding the evolution of this process.

Today, on the threshold of the transition to the third phase of economic and monetary union and of the introduction of the single European currency, we see that we have indeed succeeded in meeting the requirements of this crucial stage, despite the scepticism of those who prophesied the decline of Europe and notwithstanding political and institutional resistance to change. We may all take satisfaction in the success to which the European Parliament and its members made a decisive contribution at every stage.

Today, Portugal is a country that has, to a large extent, successfully overcome the structural backwardness that is the corollary of a backward economy. Naturally, we have not yet achieved the levels of economic progress to which we aspire, levels that are comparable to those of Europe"s most developed countries. Obviously, there have been costs involved in reconverting our economy in response to the pressures of globalization. Nonetheless, contrary to the most pessimistic forecasts, we have been able to fulfill scrupulously all the conditions for guaranteeing our full participation in the third phase of economic and monetary union within the stipulated time frames.

The continuity of this strategy, which has been formulated in such a way as to be consistent with the Treaty of Maastricht and with national interests, can be guaranteed only by a solid consensus between the main political parties of Portugal, the support of the various trends of public opinion – some which are certainly critical but all of which understand the scope of the objectives pursued –, the open‐mindedness of the economic agents, businessmen and trade unions, who are prepared to understand that essential sacrifices must be made to meet the challenges of modernisation and of the new phase in European integration.

Thus, Portugal will be among the founders of the single currency, and will be firm in its determination to guarantee the success of a strong European currency, an essential instrument of progress for our economies and of a growing European influence on the world stage. We will be among the front‐runners during this new cycle of the construction of the European Union, which affords us understandable pride, but also a sense of heightened responsibility regarding our own participation in the construction of the Europe of the next century. For the Portuguese, this step is one of particular historical significance, in that it fulfills the enlightened decision of those who wished to associate the fate of our own democracy with Portugal"s integration in Europe.

Once the dictatorship had fallen, we were able once more to embrace fully our centuries‐old vocation. We did not return to Europe, for we had always been part of it, but we assumed fully, with freedom and democracy, our own identity, our European identity, in the same way that we resumed our natural humanist and universalist tradition.

It is in this spirit that this year we celebrate our maritime exploits, with the 500th anniversary of Vasco da Gama"s historic voyage and also, in the world exhibition of Lisbon, Expo 98, the unfailing and enriching encounter between peoples and cultures, the peace and progress that we would have everybody achieve, the solidarity between nations. We consider that the importance of the oceans as world heritage, which is the central theme of Expo 98, , also justifies the creation of a special agency devoted to its protection. Lisbon is eager to host this agency, and we will offer it our fullest support and the wealth of our experience in this subject area.

Ladies and gentlemen, we have reached a turning point, and it is up to us to identify the major challenges in the European process, which will enable us to set a safe course for our common destiny. In my view, these challenges relate to the enlargement of the Union, the model for the construction of the European Union and the need to respond to the signs of crisis that are proliferating in our democratic societies.

The enlargement of the Union, to include the new democracies of central and eastern Europe within its political and institutional boundaries is, without question, the next step in the construction of the European Union, and in which its political credibility resides. To the extent that they are both intended to achieve the same end, the deepening and broadening of the European Union are inseparable.

Portugal has always, without hesitation, supported the legitimate aspirations of European countries which, following their return to democracy, wished to accede to this region of progress, freedom and security. We welcome the formula that has been found to ensure that the countries which do not join during the first phase of Union enlargement will not feel excluded.

In the eyes of the Portuguese, this subject is particularly sensitive, both on account obviously of our own experience, where accession to the European Community constituted an irreplaceable factor of convergence between the stabilization of the democratic process and our “return to Europe’ after decolonization. Therefore, for us, there can be no question that the same solidarity we received following the restoration of democracy in Portugal should be extended to the present applicant countries.

Naturally, I neither wish, nor am I able, to play down the complexity of the forthcoming enlargement; we cannot overlook the state of the economic structures that exist in the applicant countries, or the anticipated social effects of their membership. Moreover, we cannot accept that enlargement should become an element of dissolution of the European project, or that it should weaken the existing level of integration or the degree of economic and social cohesion between the states of the Union. Enlargement is not, and cannot be pursued to the detriment of the cohesion or of the degree of integration that has already been achieved.

Similarly, enlargement involves a combined effort by the Union, an effort by all, and should be approached in this frame of mind. These are the objectives which will guide our actions, firmly, but without relieving us of the responsibly of defending the need for enlargement.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the second issue that I would like to raise concerns the alternative models of the construction of the European Union which are bound, once more, to become a central topic of discussion.

It is not my intention, nor would it be appropriate, for me to speak in favour a particular model, but I would like to say that, in my opinion, the specific nature and strength of the European Union lie in the fact that it is an alliance of democratic countries and an association of sovereign entities, of ancient states and long‐standing nations, which are justifiably attached to their individuality and to their identity. The pace of the integration process has been dictated by the possibility, at each stage, of finding ways of reconciling common interests with national interests, reciprocally strengthening states and also Community institutions. Thus, the introduction of a single currency represents an immense qualitative leap forward. Consequently, we are duty‐bound to examine the need to further our political integration in such a way as to guarantee that the conditions of cohesion throughout the European Union can be maintained, democratic transparency enhanced and our identity on the international stage rendered more prominent.

I think we all agree that, in the absence of appropriate compensatory policies, the economic and monetary integration process could exacerbate economic and standard of living disparities between the regions making the Union. I would consider it to be essential for the Union to preserve its fundamental nature as an association of sovereign states, linked by common interests, a community of equals, in which the relative position of each Member State is maintained, residing on the principles of solidarity and cohesion, which are essential in guaranteeing the possibility of achieving real economic convergence.

A range of possibilities on which to test our capacity for initiative now lies open, particularly as regards the expansion of a community under the rule of law and of rights, and in the sphere of the Union"s common foreign and security policy. The development of the rule of law constitutes one of the most solid and long‐standing identifying features of European civilization. Our affinities in this area represent a solid foundation on which we may base ever more numerous initiatives, either with a view to achieving convergence between national legal models, or to laying the foundations for European citizenship. For the purpose of constructing a European political identity gradually, I would consider this course, based on the rule of law and on rights, to be more productive than any effort to impose, from the top downwards, a ready‐made and definitive European constitution, which might fail to involve the participation of the citizens of Europe.

In the light of existing circumstances, progress in the area of foreign policy will be slow. For this reason, it is particularly important that the current impetus of activities should be maintained, particularly in responding to situations of crisis. Europe should assume increased responsibilities in defending its own common interests, particularly in relation to Russia and the Ukraine, as well as in the Middle East peace process, in relations with our Mediterranean partners, and as regards Africa and Latin America. Allow me, however, to mention briefly some points that I consider to be of particular importance in this regard.

The Atlantic Alliance plays a decisive role as guarantor of regional stability, and it is in a position to confirm its central role in the architecture of European defence, but it is essential, in conjunction with the West European Union, to develop a European Defence and Security Identity and that it should be developed as a crucial and increasingly prominent factor of stability, to enhance European cooperation and institutionalize new balances in our relations with our North American allies.

Efforts must be kept up in Bosnia in order to ensure not only that hostilities are kept in check, but also to guarantee effective conditions for peace.

We also have particular responsibilities regarding our Mediterranean partners; our own security depends to a large extent on their progress and stability. The Barcelona process must be carried forward in a decisive manner, in order to avoid a clearlyunderstandable accumulation of frustrations and resentment, which severely undermines our own international credibility. As regards Turkey, this European vocation is not in any doubt, provided that its inherent models are respected. It seems to me that the conclusions of the European Council of Luxemburg put forward, without preconceptions, a realistic framework for strengthening our mutual relations.

Turning now to Africa, I know that you are aware that Portugal has offered to host a European Union‐Africa Summit during our EU presidency. I am convinced that this would be an important step in overcoming a degree of “Afro‐pessimism’, and serve to strengthen decisively our cooperation with a continent to which we are linked by so many ties.

Likewise, we should continue to give the closest attention to boosting relations between Europe and Latin America. As a member of the Ibero‐American Community, we will this year be hosting the organization"s 8th Summit, which is devoted precisely to the subject of inter‐regional integration.

In addition, I consider it to be particularly important to raise the profile of the defence of international law and human rights in constructing a common foreign policy, which constitutes a framework for defining the European Union"s international identity.

As you might expect, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in this context I would like to raise the matter of East Timor, which has assumed increasing prominence in European foreign policy, as demonstrated by the adoption of a common position by Member States and by the resolutions approved by this Parliament during the past year. Both factors reflect the Union"s active commitment to defending the rights of a martyred community which is subjugated by a regime of illegal and brutal occupation. Portugal has but one interest, I repeat one interest, as regards East Timor: to defend the rights of the Timorese, including the free and democratic exercise of its right to self determination. We are persevering, with the most constructive attitude and with the fullest respect for these principles, in our quest for a peaceful and democratic solution to the Timorese question, within the framework of the conversations that are currently being conducted under the auspices of the Secretary General of the United Nations. Moreover, as a prerequisite to an ultimate solution, immediate improvements must, I repeat must, be made in the Territory as regards respect for human rights, particularly the freeing of political prisoners and a significant reduction of the miliary presence, which are essential if a climate is to be created that is conducive to the establishment of genuine dialogue between all the parties involved. While the present crisis in Indonesia may, I hope, open up new possibilities, we are also concerned that uncontrolled violence may escalate in East Timor. I appeal to the solidarity of the European Parliament, whose initiatives have revealed for the Timorese cause an unwavering support, which is all the more necessary during this period of turmoil.

(Applause)

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the final point I would like to raise concerns the need to respond to the signs of crisis that are proliferating in our societies and which are the result, particularly, of tensions between economic modernisation and social cohesion. The dysfunctions of the market economy, with mass unemployment and with the phenomena of exclusion, inequality and poverty ever more rife, are testing the limits of tolerance of our democratic regimes. Nobody contests the fact that the European social model is currently beset by a crisis of change which, for the first time, is simultaneously, although at different stages, affecting all the states of the European Union. In this unprecedented context, the crisis of the social model is a European crisis which, with increasing urgency, demands not only specific strategies of reform in each Member State, but also, and more particularly, calls for common European responses. We need a concerted response, with a view to reinventing the social contract which is an identifying feature and corner‐stone of our democracies.

I am convinced that it would be impossible to tackle the new challenges effectively should the differences in approach by Member States to social protection and regulation of the labour market become more acute, turning them into a further element of tension within our states and, consequently, within the Union itself.

The crisis represents a unique opportunity to complement our monetary unification process with the development of a joint economic policy that is able to turn the single currency into an essential instrument of international economic competition, and a springboard for modernisation and social cohesion in Europe, without which neither sustainable growth nor democratic stability is possible.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on the foundations of the consultative and monitoring role originally assigned to it, this Parliament has gradually won competences and powers to intervene in the decision‐making process, which are consistent with its democratic legitimacy and which have proved to be essential in developing and deepening European integration. We cannot but welcome this development. I most firmly believe that the position of Parliament should be constantly enhanced. This conviction is strengthened by the upsurge of anti‐democratic trends, intolerable manifestations of racism and xenophobia, and the violence that invariably accompanies them. Economic and social progress in Europe must take place within a context of respect for the values of community, life, freedom and justice.

After Amsterdam, we must continue to advance together towards the establishment of a broad European culture of freedoms, founded on a consensus‐based model of internal security and developing ultimately into a European legal territory.

We share the perception that our citizens, the thinking women and men, who voice their opinions and who choose freely, are the seat of all power. The European integration process should pursue the unswerving aim of strengthening the conditions for exercising citizenship, increasing participation, mobilizing our citizens, their imagination and creativity ever more effectively. It is essential that our citizens" commitment to the construction of the European Union should be strengthened, to increase that solidarity which is to the advantage of all. A political architecture for Europe must be found that guarantees the necessary representation in a territory characterised by an immense cultural and linguistic diversity. Without such a guarantee, European citizenship will never amount to more than a generous intention, since the citizens of our countries will not perceive Europe as a territory for personal fulfilment. Indeed, the more citizens feel themselves to be represented in institutions, and feel these institutions to be close to them, reflecting their own concerns, the better will they understand Europe and the more open they will be to the advance of the integration process.

I do not deny that this is a difficult task, that we must all work with increasing zeal to raise the profile of the European Parliament in our societies. By bringing prestige to the European Parliament, we bring prestige to European democracy.

The European project must always be a political project, based on values and principles, a project which seeks to guarantee stability and greater economic and social prosperity. The construction of the European Union must be pursued in a manner that preserves and protects the progress already made towards integration, with continued joint and united effort. The dissolution of Europe will certainly not strengthen it.

As the legitimate representative body of the peoples of the States making up the Union, it falls to the European Parliament to play a fundamental and vital role in this process, promoting cohesion and ensuring that it remains a central priority in the context of Community policies. To this end, I am convinced that the Parliament will continue to mirror attentively the legitimate ambitions of these same peoples as a whole, and be the guardian of the European project of European ideas, defending our shared values above ephemeral interests and individual motivation.

This is the only way in which we may effectively contradict the prophets of doom and counter pessimism and loss of faith, selfish interests and ambitions. This is the only way in which we can, with confidence, embark upon this new stage of the construction of the European Union, a stage during which the Union will be enlarged to include all the European democracies, and relations between Member States grow closer, a stage characterized by the need to strengthen cohesion and solidarity between all our peoples.

This, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, is a prime aspiration for the next millennium which involves and mobilizes every individual. We should not, indeed we cannot, allow this immense opportunity to be wasted.

(Loud applause)

  President . – Thank you, Mr President, for your speech.

(The sitting closed at 12.35 p.m.)

ANNEX II

 

I. Questions to the Council

 

Question No 20 by Nikitas Kaklamanis (H−0040/98)

Subject: Outlawed party in Turkey

The decision by the Turkish Constitutional Court to outlaw the Welfare Party led by Necmettin Erbakan is a cause of deep concern among the international community. The practical abolition of democratic pluralism in Turkey is not, of course, unprecedented. In 1994, the Democracy Party was outlawed on grounds of cooperating with the Labour Party of Kurdistan. Four former Members of Parliament belonging to that party, including Leila Zana, are still in prison. Islamic fundamentalism in democratic countries cannot be countered by means of court judgments. Prohibiting diversity of opinion and freedom of expression is not a feature of democratic multiparty systems.

How will the Council respond to Turkey's undemocratic conduct, which is in breach of the basic principles of its customs union with the EU?

Answer

The Presidency issued a declaration on behalf of the European Union on the banning of the Refah party in Turkey on 21 January 1998. The EU noted with regret the decision of the Turkish Constitutional Court on 16 January 1998 to order the closure of the Welfare Party, to confiscate its property, and to ban certain present and former members of that party from being members of the Turkish Parliament or from further political activity for five years.

The European Union also noted statements by the Turkish authorities that this decision was in accordance with the provisions of the Turkish Constitution. However, the European Union is concerned at the implications for democratic pluralism and freedom of expression, and hopes that Turkey will make clear its continuing commitment to these fundamental democratic principles.

These concerns are supported by a recent ruling of the European Court of Human Rights, condemning Turkey for having banned the Former Democracy Party in 1991.

The European Council meeting in Luxembourg on 12‐13 December 1997 again underlined the necessity for the Turkish Government to meet its fundamental obligations in the field of democracy and human rights. It recalled, in line with the council position expressed at the Association Council with Turkey on 29 April 1997, that strengthening Turkey's links with the EU also depended on that country's pursuit of political reforms including the alignment of human rights standards and practices with those in the European Union.

The situation of democracy and human rights in Turkey remains high on the Council's agenda in contacts with the Turkish authorities.

Question No 21 by David Martin (H−0041/98)

Subject: Human rights in Nigeria

In the light of continuing reports of human rights abuses in Nigeria, would the Council raise with the Nigerian Government the serious concerns for the safety of Gbenga Adebusuyi following reports by Amnesty International of his torture and ill‐treatment.

Answer

The Council is concerned at reports of ill‐treatment by the Nigerian authorities of Dr Adebusuyi who, it understands, was charged with treason, with fifteen others, in March 1997, although he is said to have been held in custody for some time before that.

The European Union has repeatedly expressed its grave concern at the human rights situation in Nigeria, including the detention of political prisoners. The Council of Ministers reflected this on 28 November 1997 with its decision to extend the EU Common Position on Nigeria of 4 November 1995 until 1 November 1998. Most recently, on 26 December 1997 the Luxembourg Presidency issued a declaration on behalf of the EU following the arrests of General Diya and eleven others accused of attempting to carry out a coup d'état. This made it clear that the EU could not accept a repetition of the events of 1995 concerning the trial and execution of Ken Saro‐Wiwa and his Ogoni co‐defendants.

The EU has intervened on many occasions in different fora on behalf of political prisoners in Nigeria and will continue to do so.

Question No 22 by Hugh McMahon (H−0043/98)

Subject: Possible amendments to the Acquired Rights Directive

With reference to the priorities laid down by the President‐in‐Office during Parliament's January 1998 part‐session, can the President‐in‐Office inform Parliament whether the Council intends to pursue possible amendments to the Acquired Rights Directive in order to clarify the scope of this very important piece of employment protection legislation?

Answer

Work within the Council on the amended proposal for a Directive concerning the safeguarding of employees' rights in the event of transfers of undertakings, businesses or parts of businesses – which was submitted by the Commission in February 1997 – has resumed under the UK Presidency.

This proposal aims at amending the 1977 Directive (77/187/EEC) so as to take into account recent developments in the case law of the Court of Justice and particularly the protection of the rights of workers and their adequate information and consultation. In that context, one of the key questions to be addressed by the Council will be that of the scope of the Directive.

The UK Presidency is hoping that a political agreement may be reached on the text during the Council session of June 1998.

Question No 23 by Peter Truscott (H−0049/98)

Subject: European Conference

Could the President‐in‐Office outline the plans for the European Conference scheduled for 12 March and the efforts to ensure that the enlargement process is truly inclusive for all the applicant countries?

Answer

As the Honourable Member will be aware, the Luxembourg European Council established the inclusive nature of the enlargement process. A key element of this is the European Conference which the UK Presidency will inaugurate in London on 12 March. Luxembourg invites the participation on an equal footing of the existing EU Member States, the ten Central European applicants, Cyprus and Turkey to discuss issues of common interest. The Accession Process will be launched on 30 March at Foreign Minister level with the Central Europeans and Cyprus. And accession negotiations will be opened with the five Central Europeans and Cyprus on 31 March. All countries will proceed at their own individual pace, and those not yet negotiating can start as soon as they are ready.

Question No 24 by Paul Rübig (H−0052/98)

Subject: Crime in Brussels

We talk a great deal about international crime and combating crime, but we are not even able to guarantee our own safety and the safety of our staff in the very heart of the European Union.

In the past two months, an Austrian Member was the victim of a brutal mugging in Brussels. What is more, in my office alone two trainees and a female member of our press office staff were threatened, robbed or mugged. Many colleagues from other countries and other political groups can report similar incidents.

Does the Council recognize the need for action to deal with this situation and, if so, who should take it? In particular, does it believe that it is the responsibility of the local authorities to eliminate this glaring breakdown in security?

Answer

In reply to the Honourable Member's question, I should point out that the Council has never been called upon to discuss the problems raised in it.

The Honourable Member is aware that problems in connection with the safety of persons, property and goods in the territory of the Member States fall within the exclusive jurisdiction of the police and judicial authorities of the Member States concerned.

In this particular case, the facts to which the Honourable Member alludes come within the jurisdiction of the Belgian police authorities.

Question No 25 by Brian Simpson (H−0053/98)

Subject: Trans‐European networks

Does the Council of Ministers still see the priority projects within the Trans‐European Transport Networks as being important? Furthermore, what progress has been made in implementing these schemes, particularly the upgrading of the main West Coast railway line in the UK?

Answer

In the context of setting up the Trans‐European Networks, the Essen European Council placed particular emphasis on the implementation of a number of projects, including the West Coast Mainline in the United Kingdom.

This interest was expressed in Article 19 and in Annex III of Decision No 1692/96/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 July 1996 on Community guidelines for the development of the Trans‐European Transport Networks. The Council's position on the matter is unchanged, and the Decision, including the project to which the Honourable Member refers in his question, therefore remains valid.

It should also be noted that it is the Commission's task to monitor the progress of work on the trans‐European networks.

Question No 26 by Anne McIntosh (H−0059/98)

Subject: The Second EC Driving Licence Directive

Will the Council reconsider the Driving Licence Directive and, in particular, the impact that its provisions will have on diabetic drivers and their right to drive 3.5‐7.5 tonne vehicles?

Does the Council agree that the standards imposed, under this Directive, discriminate against diabetics, causing a great deal of personal distress?

Answer

On 29 July 1991 the Council adopted Directive 91/439/EEC, which entered into force on 1 July 1996.

Under the Directive, it is for each Member State to determine the scope of the very exceptional cases which would justify issuing or renewing a licence for persons suffering from diabetes mellitus and requiring insulin treatment. The Council would point out that it is not for it to adopt a position on whether the Community provisions in question should be amended, as any initiative relating to the specific question put by the Honourable Member falls to the Commission.

It should be noted that Directive 97/26/EC set up a Committee on Driving Licences to assist the Commission in adapting to scientific and technical progress, inter alia, Annex III and in particular the ‚minimum standards’ of physical and mental fitness for driving a power‐driven vehicle.

The Council would also point out that the Directive does not discriminate against certain diseases, as Annex III specifies most diseases which could affect driving. The diseases not specified there fall within the scope of the Directive under the general provision contained in Annex III.

Question No 27 by Hans Lindqvist (H−0061/98)

Subject: Dental amalgam

In 1986, the Swedish Board of Health and Welfare classified amalgam as a toxicologically unsuitable material for dental repairs and the Ministry of Health and Social Affairs ruled that it should cease to be used for children in 1995 and adults in 1997.

Various pressure groups, non cost‐neutral pricing by the Swedish Social Insurance Board and sheer reluctance to change ingrained methods etc. have held up the phasing‐out process. EU rules on medical materials have caused further difficulties. The EU has set up an ad hoc group which has drawn up a draft evaluation of amalgam, the entire content of which has obviously been dictated by the advocates of amalgam. No representatives of patients' organizations or organizations representing researchers and dentists who have realized the harmfulness of amalgam have been allowed to take part.

What is the Council's view of Sweden's being able to maintain its ban on the use of amalgam in the future?

Answer

The ad hoc group, which drew up the draft evaluation of dental amalgam the Member referred to in his question, is apparently a group set up by the Commission.

In any event, no proposals on this subject have been referred to the Council, which is therefore unable to answer the Member's question.

Question No 28 by James Nicholson (H−0073/98)

Subject: Objective I regions

Has the Council had any discussion on future Objective I status for regions which currently have Objective I status within the EU?

Answer

The Council discussed the Commission's communication ‚Agenda 2000’ before the Luxembourg European Council, including the Commission's suggestions for the reform of the Structural and Cohesion Funds and eligibility for Objective 1. The European Council invited the Commission to submit formal proposals at the earliest opportunity in the light of the initial discussions. We expect these proposals in March. The Council will then consider the Regulations in detail.

Question No 29 by Maj Theorin (H−0076/98)

Subject: Kurdish refugees

At the beginning of this year, many people have fled from Turkey to the European Union. Turkey has come under intense pressure from the EU to stem the flow of refugees and, as a result, has carried out mass arrests of people suspected of planning to flee the country.

Does the Council think it reasonable to criticize Turkey for failing to respect human rights whilst the EU, instead of giving protection to refugees from Turkey, is urging Turkey to stop them leaving the country?

Answer

The Council recognizes that a key element in tackling the problem of the influx of migrants from Iraq and the neighbouring region is to establish effective cooperation with the Turkish government. This point is clearly spelled out in the Presidency's 46‐Point EU Action Plan on the Influx of Migrants adopted by the General Affairs Council on 26 January.

Action Point No (B) 2 of the Plan states that the Presidency, with the Commission, will take forward discussions with the Turkish government with the aim of identifying and implementing specific means of improved co‐operation.

The Council will continue to give humanitarian concerns their proper weight in responding to the influx of illegal migrants, and the Action Plan highlights the importance of the Presidency's close collaboration with the UNHCR. Member States must also ensure that they continue to provide protection in accordance with international law. But equally the procedures for seeking and granting asylum should not be open to abuse. Member States also recognize the need to address the involvement of organized crime in the trafficking of illegal immigrants.

While the Council recognizes the difficulties Turkey faces in tackling the issue of illegal migrants, and welcomes the co‐operation that the Turkish government has offered to date, the Council will continue to urge Turkey to improve its general record on human rights. The questions of Turkey's human rights standards and the respect of its minorities are key elements in the future development of relations between the EU and the Turkey, as indicated by the Luxembourg Council Conclusions of 13 December 1997.

Question No 30 by David Thomas (H−0077/98)

Subject: Agenda 2000 and food safety

The EU is preparing for significant structural changes via the 'Agenda 2000' process which will, inter alia, bring about important changes in food production. Assuming ratification of the draft Amsterdam Treaty, is it not desirable, as part of the process of bringing Europe closer to its citizens, to bring about significant improvements in cooperation on food safety, public health, occupational health and information on lifestyle? How does the Council envisage progress towards this parallel 'Agenda 2000' for the good health of European citizens?

Answer

The Council agrees with the Honourable Member of the European Parliament on the necessity to promote significant improvement in cooperation on food safety, public health and information on lifestyle, it stresses the fact that the Treaty of Amsterdam contains a revised Article 129a that, once the Treaty has entered into force, should contribute to the completion of such an objective.

Regarding the idea of a parallel ‚Agenda 2000’ for the good health of European citizens, the Council underlines the fact that the competence to present such a proposal belongs to the Commission. Nevertheless, the Council regularly reaffirms its concerns on these matters on the occasion of the discussion of the several propositions of directive under its examination at present.

Question No 31 by Clive Needle (H−0078/98)

Subject: Clinical trials of pharmaceutical products

Does the Council agree that transparent clinical trials of pharmaceutical products is necessary at EU level both for the effective safe operation of the internal market and for good health? What progress is being made this year to achieve this?

Answer

With the introduction of the first Community legislation concerning pharmaceuticals in 1965, twin principles of protection of public health and free movement of pharmaceutical products were established. The legislation passed in that year requires that medicinal products must have a marketing authorization prior to being placed on the market in the European Union. Further, the criteria upon which access to the market is determined – quality, safety and efficacy – have been clearly set out. Particularly the latter two criteria generally have to rely on clinical trials in human subjects for demonstration purposes.

The standards for the conduct of clinical trials have been developed progressively, both within the European Union and internationally. These standards were codified in the European Union guideline on Good Clinical Practice (GCP) in 1990 and are followed in clinical research by the pharmaceutical industry.

Since January 1997, the internationally harmonized GCP have been incorporated into clinical practice within the European Union by virtue of their inclusion in 'The rules governing medicinal products in the European Union' published by the Commission in accordance with the annex to Directive 75/318/EEC on the approximation of the laws of Member States relating to analytical, pharmacotoxicological and clinical standards and protocols in respect of the testing of medicinal products, as amended.

Since such guidelines are not binding, the harmonized legislative framework at European Union level will assure the same level of patient protection and scientific standards as well as a simplification of administrative and regulatory requirements for companies which intend to conduct multi‐centre clinical trials in more than one Member State of the European Union.

The Council therefore welcomes the draft proposal presented last autumn by the Commission which aims at harmonizing procedures for the commencement of clinical trials.

All Member States have their own arrangements relating to the commencement of a clinical trial. However, the requirements are not the same and thus, currently, if the trial is conducted in multiple investigational sites, the same trial must comply with different national provisions resulting in delays of up to several months. As major pharmaceutical innovations rely, for the demonstration of safety and efficacy, on multi‐centre clinical trials, it is important that clinical research should not be inhibited by unnecessary administrative burdens.

Equally important, the information to be submitted to Member States prior to commencement of a clinical trial will be harmonized, both in content and format, in order to ensure that all Member States receive the same information. Included, as part of this information, are the necessary toxicological and pharmacological tests in animals performed as a pre‐determination of risk for human health.

Another aspect of the draft proposal concerns harmonization of the application of the Good Clinical Practice. The draft proposal contains a delegation of power to the Commission to adopt a Directive containing the detailed principles and guidelines in Good Clinical Practice which meets the agreement of the Council.

The Council welcomes also that the draft proposal provides for continuous information on clinical trials to be available to all competent authorities of the Member States. Thus, selected elements of the initial application, as well as amendments of the trial along with the summary notification at the end of the trial, whether this is due to an early interruption of the trial or in line with the anticipated duration, would be registered in a database, accessible only to competent authorities.

The importance which the Council attaches to the subject of the conduct of clinical trials in the European Union is underlined by the fact that the Luxembourg Presidency started discussions on the draft proposal at expert level directly after its reception and that already two further meetings of the responsible working party have taken place in January. The objective of the United Kingdom Presidency is to advance work as far as possible.

Question No 32 by Nuala Ahern (H−0082/98)

Subject: Operation of the MOX plant at Sellafield

What consideration has been given by the Presidency of the implications for nuclear proliferation and security controls over plutonium of the plans by British Nuclear Fuels to operate a MOX plant for plutonium fuels at Sellafield?

Question No 33 by James Fitzsimons (H−0138/98)

Subject: Sellafield discharges and leaks

As the Council is aware, BNFL is hoping to increase discharges into the air and to decrease but not eliminate discharges into the sea from its Sellafield plant. Does the Council agree that, in the light of yet another incident at Sellafield involving a leak at that nuclear plant, the only authorization that should be given to BNFL and Sellafield is for its immediate and permanent closure?

Joint Answer

In reply to the questions put by the Honourable Member, I would like to stress that the Council shares the views of the Honourable Member on the importance of non proliferation in the nuclear field and can assure her that this preoccupation is always kept in mind when the Council deals with nuclear issues.

In this context, the Council agrees that security control is essential and would point out that the MOX plants situated in the territory of the Member States of the European Union are subject to current Community legislation on security controls, in particular provisions of Chapter 7 of the Euratom Treaty dealing with safeguards.

More generally, the Council wishes to point out that control and safeguards measures on the manufacture of MOX are applied at national, Community and international level.

The Council attaches great importance to the protection of the public against the dangers arising from ionizing radiation. In 1996, a new Council Directive 96/29/Euratom (the Basic Safety Standards Directive) reinforcing the level of protection of workers and the general public was adopted. This Directive lays down strict limits of exposure to radiation taking into account the latest scientific and technological data.

In this context, discharges are subject to authorization, given by the Member State concerned, which shall specify compliance with the provisions of the 1996 Directive laying down basic safety standards on the matter. In particular, doses resulting from discharges should be as low as reasonably achievable.

The Council considers that strict compliance with the provisions of the Basic Safety Standards Directive should ensure for a normal operation at any nuclear plant.

Question No 34 by David Bowe (H−0084/98)

Subject: Urban air pollution

Given the severe public health problems caused by poor air quality in cities throughout the Union, what action is the Council proposing to take, in terms of both environmental and transport measures, to combat urban air pollution?

Answer

Whilst recalling that it is on the Commission the Treaty confers the power to make proposals, the Council emphasizes at all times the need to ensure that environmental concerns are taken into consideration in all areas of EU policy making, in particular by achieving integration between environment and transport policies.

Improving air quality is an important issue for the Council and a central part of the Presidency's environmental objectives. Council is currently considering the Commission's proposals for Directives relating to limit values for sulphur dioxide, oxides of nitrogen, particulate matter and lead in ambient air; the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels; and measures to be taken against air pollution by emissions from motor vehicles (light commercial vehicles). Council also adopted Conclusions on a Community strategy to combat acidification on 16 December 1997.

Moreover, the attention of the Honourable Member is drawn to the fact that in recognition of the important synergies between environmental and transport measures, especially in improving air quality, the Council intends to hold a joint session of Environment and Transport Ministers in June 1998.

Question No 35 by Ulf Holm (H−0089/98)

Subject: Marketing meat in non‐Community countries

On 20 January the Council of Ministers of Agriculture decided to promote the consumption of high quality beef by continuing to co‐finance production at 60 %, publicizing the new meat labelling system and marketing EU meat in non‐Community countries.

It is extraordinary that the EU should thus be subsidizing the sale of beef out of public funds, but this is regrettable not only on economic grounds. These measures will also in part maintain the over production of meat within the EU, and the dumping of our meat in non‐Community countries will eliminate local producers which is likely to impoverish those countries and increase their dependency on imports.

How will the Council compensate the non‐Community countries for the damage they will suffer with the elimination of their local producers?

Answer

On 20 January 1998, the Council held a discussion on a proposal from the Commission concerning measures to promote consumption of Community quality beef and veal. The Council did not make any final decisions at that meeting.

It can be noted, however, that the Commission has proposed changes to the existing measures (Regulation (EC) N° 2067/92) as well as the introduction of two new measures. The new measures concern publicity for the new labelling system adopted by the Council in 1997 (Regulation (EC) n° 820/97) and promotional activities for Community beef in third countries.

Without prejudice to the outcome of the Council deliberations, I note in particular that the new measures proposed do not envisage that the Community would sell beef directly or that it would subsidize the sale of beef in third countries, but rather that it would part‐finance suitable promotional measures to promote Community quality beef and veal in third countries.

The Council shall resume its examination of the various measures contained in the proposal at its February session.

Question No 36 by Per Gahrton (H−0092/98)

Subject: The Council's intentions regarding relations with China

According to reports in the media the Council is planning to seek a compromise with the People's Republic of China concerning human rights, under which the EU would steer clear of any resolutions critical of China at the UN Commission for Human Rights in Geneva in return for China's release of the political prisoner, Wang Pen, and signing of the UN Convention on political rights. Is this true? If so, how can it be reconciled with the European Parliament's resolutions on China?

Question No 37 by Graham Watson (H−0146/98)

Subject: Human rights in China

Will the President‐in‐Office disclose his plans to raise the issue of human rights in China at the forthcoming Geneva meeting, the ASEM meeting and the proposed EU‐China bilateral meeting, and will he explain how these dovetail with the UK's ethical foreign policy?

Joint Answer

As the honourable Members of Parliament know, the human rights situation in China is an issue of constant concern for the Union. All EU Member States share a common objective in wanting to achieve a tangible improvement in human rights in China.

The issue of human rights is constantly on the agenda in the contacts between the Union, its individual Member States and China. I myself addressed these issues with my Chinese counterpart when I was in Beijing this January.

Since last year's Commission on Human Rights, the EU and China have engaged in a series of substantial discussions on human rights. Two meetings at experts level took place last year, one in October in Luxembourg and a second one in Beijing early December. Another meeting of this kind is to take place in the margins of a joint EU/China seminar in Beijing at the end of February on the protection of human rights and the administration of justice. A further round of talks is most likely to take place in London next May.

Before the start of this year's CHR the Council will evaluate the human rights situation in China as well as the ongoing EU‐China dialogue on human rights and the human rights cooperation programme it agreed with China with a view to arriving at a joint EU position at the CHR.

Question No 38 by Gary Titley (H−0095/98)

Subject: Employment and training

In the hi‐tech global economy that Europe competes in, skills and retraining of Europe's workers are essential if we are to remain competitive. Given the different approaches of Member States to promote skills and retraining, what role will 'employability' play?

Question No 39 by Peter Skinner (H−0096/98)

Subject: Employment

Given that 18 million people are unemployed across the European Union and that this constitutes an enormous waste of human resources, can the Presidency tell the Parliament of the action plans and spread of best practice that will affect the rump of unemployed people across Europe?

Joint Answer

I agree with the honourable Parliamentarians, both that the appalling total of 18 million unemployed people across the European Union is an atrocious waste of human and economic resources and that improving the skills of Europe's workers is a key part of the action we must take to tackle the problem.

The New Employment Chapter in the Treaty agreed at the Amsterdam European Council and the Conclusions of that Council, along with the Employment Guidelines adopted at the extraordinary European Council on Employment: on 15 December 1997 have given a new and substantial impetus to the Community's work on employment matters.

The Luxembourg Council agreed, inter alia, upon an overall strategy involving the co‐ordination of Member State's employment policies and a process involving the preparation of national action plans, their analysis by the Council and exchanges of good practice, in particular through the Employment and Labour Market Committee.

The United Kingdom Presidency is determined to carry forward the agenda set out by the Luxembourg Council and has asked all Member States to present their National Employment Action Plans by the middle of April, to enable progress to be reviewed at the Cardiff European Council in June.

The Presidency is bringing together the work of the Social Affairs and Education Councils around the theme of employability. Promoting life on learning will be a key element of that theme. Particular objectives, in addition to the production of action plans, will be:

‐  agreement on objectives and priorities for the new generation of education, training and youth programmes and for the ESF after 2 000

‐  agreement on a package of skills and mobility measures

‐  taking forward a number of measures to underpin fair minimum standards at work.

Exchanges of good practice on employability issues, will be a key feature of Presidency activity, for example at the joint informal meeting of Education and Social Affairs Ministers in London in March and in a number of the supporting Presidency events.

Question No 40 by Ole Krarup (H−0097/98)

Subject: Schengen cooperation

Under Article 5(1) of the Protocol on the position of Denmark annexed to the Amsterdam Treaty, Denmark has six months within which to decide whether to implement in its national law decisions to build upon the Schengen acquis taken by the other participating countries under the Protocol integrating the Schengen acquis into the framework of the European Union.

If the Danish Folketing decides not to implement such decisions, under Article 5(2) the Member States will consider 'appropriate measures to be taken'.

What types of 'measures' are intended, and what voting procedures apply to decisions on 'measures'?

Answer

In reply to the question of the Honourable Member, it must be stressed that even though the Treaty of Amsterdam has been signed, the procedures of ratification are still under way.

Under these circumstances the Council cannot take a view on interpretation questions of the Treaty or the Protocols annexed to it; it follows from this that the Council is not in a position to interpret questions like those posed in the final paragraph of the question.

Question No 41 by Alex Smith (H−0104/98)

Subject: Proposal for changes to the common market in bananas

With regard to the proposal for changes to the common organization of the market in bananas, the Commission has repeatedly stated that the proposal is only one option open to the EU at a response to the findings of the WTO Panel.

Is the Council satisfied that the option proposed by the Commission is indeed the most valid one, and could the Council comment on whether it is looking at other options and, if so, what those options entail?

Does the Council agree that, by continually responding to and accommodating criticisms from the WTO, the EU is effectively undermining its credibility as a partner in economic agreements with its partners throughout the world? What action is the Council taking to ensure that the terms of the European Union's policy are determined by the Institutions of the European Union and its Member States rather than the terms and conditions of the World Trade Organization and its non‐EU members?

Answer

Following the World Trade Organization's findings on the compatibility of the market organization for bananas with WTO rules, the Commission presented to the Council, on 16 January 1998, its Proposal for a Council Regulation amending the present Regulation No 404/93 on the common organization of the market in bananas.

The proposal is presently under examination by the Council. Therefore you will understand that it is too early for me to speculate on the possible outcome of this examination and to anticipate on the final position of the Council. Moreover, I observe that, in finalizing its position, the Council will wish to be aware of the opinions of both the European Parliament and the Economic and Social Committee, once these have been received.

On your wider point, I would mention that the consolidation and strengthening of the multilateral system remains one of the main priorities of the Council in the field of external economic relations. The EU believes in the rule of law for international trade, and it is to the World Trade Organization that we must look to establish that rule of law.

Question No 42 by Karl Habsburg‐Lothringen (H−0110/98)

Subject: Creation of an artificial region called the 'West Balkans'

Is it true that the Council has decided to create a region in Europe which will be called the 'West Balkans' and consist of Albania, Serbia and Montenegro, Macedonia, Bosnia‐Hercegovina and Croatia? Does the Council realize that, if it were to do so, it would be flagrantly flying in the face of history and the will of broad sections of the population? Is the Council aware that, for example, Croatia has always been, and still is, historically and culturally a western‐oriented Central European state and that such facts cannot be blithely ignored in a supremely imperialistic manner?

Answer

The change in denomination of the Council ‚Working Group on Former Yugoslavia’ to the Council ‚Western Balkans Working Group’ is due to the following reasons, which are merely administrative and not political:

1) in the majority of Ministries of Foreign Affairs in EU capitals, experts who deal with Albania are also those who deal with former Yugoslavia. It was therefore logical and cost‐effective to treat the countries in the same Group.

2) Albania, Bosnia‐Herzegovina, Croatia, Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY), Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM) are all covered by the EU regional approach and conditionality policy. They should thus be treated together.
