3) The necessity for a global and integrated approach to the problem of ethnic Albanian minorities in FRY and FYROM calls for the inclusion of Albania in the same Group as the ex‐Yugoslavia Republics.

Croatia cannot be treated in the ‚Central Europe Working Group’, as it does not have a Europe Agreement, as all other countries covered by this Group have.

In creating the denomination of the ‚Western Balkans Working Group’, the Council had no intention nor ambition to artificially create a new region in Europe. The changing of the name of one of its Working Groups was due merely to administrative and practical reasons.

Question No 43 by Anne Van Lancker (H−0113/98)

Subject: Preparations for integrating the Schengen acquis in the Treaty

According to the Treaty, the Schengen measures on checks at external borders, asylum, immigration and judicial cooperation in civil matters should come under Title IV of the Treaty establishing the European Community, while the provisions on police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters should come under Title VI of the Treaty on European Union, the third pillar. What should the SIS (and later the EIS) come under? Article 286 of the Treaty says that from 1 January 1999 Community decisions on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing and free movement of personal data shall apply to the institutions and bodies set up by, or on the basis of, the Treaty. What arrangements will there be for the protection of privacy in the SIS?

Answer

According to Article 2, paragraph 1 of the Protocol in the Treaty of Amsterdam integrating the Schengen acquis into the framework of the European Union, the Council has to determine, in conformity with the relevant provisions of the Treaties, the legal basis for each of the provisions or decisions which constitute the Schengen acquis.

In order to prepare a Council decision to that effect, which will be taken when the Treaty of Amsterdam will enter into force, a working group of the Council has been set up, which had its first meetings under the Luxembourg presidency, and is presently continuing its work under the UK presidency.

The question of the determination of the legal basis or bases for the provisions of the Schengen acquis relating to the Schengen Information System (SIS), as well as for those relating to the protection of personal data contained in the SIS, is under consideration, but it is much too early to report any position.

Question No 44 by Lone Dybkjær (H−0120/98)

Subject: Commission answer to a question concerning the comprehensibility of a Directive

The Commission's answer to question No 56 (H−0860/97)(1) , in which I criticized its proposal amending European Parliament and Council Directive 95/2/EC(2) for being incomprehensible, was that it did not share my opinion that the proposal was incomprehensible but would be pleased to answer any technical questions that I might have about the proposal.

Does the UK Presidency share the Commission's views on this Directive, which has been amended many times over the years? Does it consider the Directive to be well suited for ensuring public participation and for restoring contact between the peoples of Europe and the European Union, which are amongst the aims stated by the Presidency in its work programme?

Given that the Directive in question actually affects many people quite directly, since they suffer allergic reactions to additives, could the Council envisage using it as a kind of test case to establish whether EU legislation is understandable or could be made more understandable to a wider audience?

Answer

The interesting question which the Honourable Member raises, concern a case of clarifying the details of a proposal amending an existing legislative text, which therefore already applies and has already been subject to one minor amendment.

It is clear that the text in question, since it relates to food additives, is bound to show a certain degree of technical complexity, hence the offer made by the Commission in its reply to Question H−860/97, to which the Honourable Member refers in her present question to the Council.

Furthermore, I should like to confirm to the Honourable Member that the European Union is in fact involved in a process aiming to reduce the distance between European citizens and the Community whilst offering greater transparency in these texts and procedures. In this respect I would like to emphasize efforts made through the codification of existing texts as provided for in the Interinstitutional Agreement of 1994 setting up on an accelerated working method for codification. This consists in replacing a legislative act which has been amended several times by a single codified text, without changing its substance. Simplification of existing texts is also a concern which is being addressed in the present directive. As to the specific question of the Honourable Member it is difficult to answer because she does not indicate what are the obscure points in the Commission's proposal which, to her mind, call for an explanation.

Question No 45 by Christine Oddy (H−0125/98)

Subject: Bombing in Kandy, Sri Lanka

Given the recent bomb explosion in Kandy, Sri Lanka, what steps will be European Council take to try to promote a peace dialogue in Sri Lanka?

Answer

On [6] February the Presidency on behalf of the European Union issued a declaration regarding the bombing of the Temple of the Tooth in Kandy. In this declaration the European Union strongly condemned the attack which was described as brutal and malign.

Furthermore, the declaration expressed firm hope that efforts to reach a political settlement in Sri Lanka would continue. The Union also appealed to all political and social groups, which so far had not done so, to commit themselves to a peaceful political solution.

More information about the Union´s position on the conflict in Sri Lanka may be found in the answers to parliamentary questions No 213/97, H−512/97 and H−336/97.

Question No 46 by Bernie Malone (H−0128/98)

Subject: Iranian woman – Zoleykhah Kadkhoda – sentenced to death

Can the Council Presidency indicate what representations for clemency it has made or is planning to make on behalf of Zoleykhah Kadkhoda, a twenty‐year old Iranian woman who was sentenced to death last year for engaging in sexual relations outside marriage.

Immediately after the sentence was pronounced, Zoleykhah was taken out to be stoned to death. The sentence was carried out. Zoleykhah was then taken to a mortuary but miraculously began to breathe. She was taken to hospital where she has been recovering from her injuries.

It is now feared however the Zoleykhah may be subjected to a second execution.

Would the Council Presidency not agree that the EU must signal to the Iranian Government in the strongest possible terms both its opposition to the death penalty and its distaste at the treatment meted out to Zoleykhah Kadkhoda.

Answer

The Council has no specific knowledge of the case raised by the Honourable Member, but it does call on all countries to abolish the death penalty and shares the Honourable Member's abhorrence of cruel and inhumane practices such as stoning.

There is unfortunately little the Council, or individual Member States, can do to influence other countries' legal systems and practices. But the Council does raise both general and specific human rights issue with Iran and other countries that violate human rights and standards which we hold to be universal.

The end of the EU‐Iran Critical Dialogue in the wake of the so‐called Mykonos trial limited further our modest possibilities of influencing Iranian behaviour in the area of human rights; the Council, however, hopes that this situation will improve, following the new Iranian Government's stated commitment to respect the rule of law and their emphasis on the need for a dialogue of civilizations.

Question No 47 by Richard Howitt (H−0129/98)

Subject: The need to eradicate asbestos in Europe

In response to an enquiry from my constituent, Mrs J. Pirie, whose husband died recently of the asbestos‐related disease mesophelioma, can the Council indicate what progress is being made to eradicate all types of asbestos from European territory? Will the Council use the meeting of the Working Group on Asbestos on 3 March 1998 to review the results of the study carried out on the economic impact of such a ban on the Member States and formulate a film recommendation for the Health Council meeting on 30 April 1998, with a view to exerting pressure on the seven Member States who have not yet introduced national legislation to remove white asbestos altogether? When will the outcome of the aforementioned study be made available to Parliament?

Answer

The United Kingdom Presidency, which shares the concerns of the Honourable Member regarding the dangers of white asbestos, has put the matter on the agenda of the Social Questions Working Party.

Work is at the present at the stage of a preliminary exchange of views, but is being pursued with a view to the issue being discussed at the Council session (Labour and Social Affairs) on 7 April 1998.

The Council has not, at present, received any proposal from the Commission, in accordance with Article 129 of the EC Treaty, regarding a ban on asbestos.

Further remarks

A recommendation in respect of Article 129 would not be an appropriate basis for standards relating to the sale and use of the said substance.

On the other hand, the Article contains a general clause according to which requirements relating to health protection form a part of the Community's other policies and should be taken into consideration in any proposal/decision relating to such policies.

NB: ‐ Protection of workers (cf. directive in social field)

‐  Code of practice for sale and use (cf. internal market)

Question No 48 by Vassilis Ephremidis (H−0131/98)

Subject: Statements by Mr Cook concerning Turkey's participation in the European Conference

According to recent statements made by the UK Foreign Secretary, Mr Robin Cook, there are no special preconditions for Turkey's participation in the European Conference and the essential first step at the moment is for Turkey to accept the invitation to take part in the European Conference extended by the summit meeting in Luxembourg. A great many similar statements have been made recently by senior officials in the EU and Member States' governments. H−0131/98)

Will the Council say whether it is a condition of Turkey's participation in the European Conference 'to accept the criteria and subscribe to the principles' to which, as stipulated by the Luxembourg Council's conclusions, 'the members of the Conference must share a common commitment' and whether the statements by Mr Cook and other EU officials are contrary to European Council decisions?

Answer

In accordance with the Luxembourg European Council conclusions, the offer to participate in the European Conference is addressed to Turkey as it is to Cyprus and the applicant States of central and eastern Europe. It is implicit that those attending the European Conference, subscribe to the principles set out at Luxembourg. The Council has taken no further position on the matter but will no doubt discuss on 23 February the preparations for the first meeting of the Conference on 12 March in London.

Question No 49 by Anneli Hulthén (H−0132/98)

Subject: EU support for organizations whose activities run counter to UN drugs conventions

It has come to my notice that, in both 1996 and 1997, EU financial support was given to organizations such as European Cities on Drug Policy (ECDP), whose aims include the legalization of drugs and legalized prescription of heroin, i.e. to organizations advocating drugs policies which are incompatible with UN conventions on drugs.

Does the Council take the view that EU support for organizations whose activities make it difficult for Member States to fulfil commitments deriving from the UN conventions in question is consistent with the EU's desired relationship with the UN?

Question No 50 by Brian Crowley (H−0140/98)

Subject: UN General Assembly on Drugs

Will the Council outline what preparatory work is being undertaken by the UK Presidency before the UN General Assembly on Drugs takes place next June with a view to supporting and strengthening EU and international action against drugs, and will it also outline what contribution the EU is making to the Declaration on the Guiding Principles of Drug‐Demand Reduction which is to be adopted at the Assembly.

Joint Answer

1.  In reply to the question put by Mrs Hulthén, I wish to state that the Council is not competent for the matter referred to by the Honourable Member of Parliament.

2.  In reply to the question of Mr Crowley it should be pointed out that the Member States and the Commission have been actively coordinating their positions and taken common stands in preparatory meetings for the special General Assembly Session on drugs from 8/10 June 1998 in New York. The suggestions of the European Union in regard to precursors, synthetic drugs, money laundering, demand reduction and alternative development have been largely taken into account in papers resulting from these preparatory meetings that were held in July, October and December 1997 in Vienna.

A preparatory meeting for the special General Assembly Session on drugs, will take place on 16/20 March 1998 in Vienna. At this meeting prior attention will be given to the political declaration which suggests to eradicate poppy and coca cultivation before 2008. Member States and Commission are coordinating their positions in competent Council bodies. These bodies are also examining a communication from the Commission to the Council and the European Parliament with a view to establishing a common European Union platform for the special session of the UN General Assembly on International cooperation in the fight against drugs.

In general it can be said that the integrated transpillar approach of the Union in regard to drugs is reflected in documents resulting from preparatory meetings.

Question No 51 by Concepció Ferrer (H−0135/98)

Subject: Situation in Equatorial Guinea

The still obscure recent events on the island of Bioko (Equatorial Guinea) have led to claims by the local democratic opposition that members of the Bubi ethnic group have been arrested and tortured, while the threat of the death penalty still hangs over four former Spanish ex‐legionaries of Equatorial Guinean origin.

In view of the above, has the Council established the real impact of the events, and can it state how far the accusations of major human rights violations by the government are backed up by the facts? Is the Council aware that four Spanish citizens of Equatorial Guinean origin are under arrest?

Should the accusations prove to be true, what measures does it intend to adopt to bolster the national democratization process promoted by President Obiang?

Answer

The Council is aware of reports that a number of people belonging to the Bubi ethnic group native to Bioko Island, one of the two parts of Equatorial Guinea have been under arrest since 21 January, suspected of belonging to or supporting the independence movement (Movimento para la Autodeterminacion de la Isla de Bioko (MAIB)). The Equatorial Guinean Government has accused MAIB of attacking military and civilian targets on Bioko. On 5 February the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Mr Oyono is reported to have confirmed that several people had been arrested. Among those arrested were one Nigerian and four Spaniards of Equatorial Guinean origin, all alleged to be MAIB members. Mr Oyono confirmed that they faced the death penalty. MAIB is reported to have denied all charges of being behind these attacks or other acts of violence. It claims that more than 800 of the Bubi people have been arrested.

The Council will continue to monitor developments in Equatorial Guinea and will raise its concerns about human rights in Equatorial Guinea in its report to the 1998 UN Commission on Human rights. President Obiang visited the Commission on 30 October 1997 to present his programme for democratisation and to request a resumption of aid that was suspended in 1992. The Commission responded that the progressive resumption of aid would be linked to progress achieved in respect for human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law.

Question No 52 by Katerina Daskalaki (H−0137/98)

Subject: Wholesale looting of Orthodox monuments in Turkey

Following the recent attacks by 'persons unknown' on the Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople, the attack by 'persons unknown' on the shrine of Ayios Therapon in Istanbul – which was never investigated – during which not only was the monument looted but the elderly church sexton brutally murdered, another incident has occurred on Imbros. This time 'persons unknown' broke into the Church of the Annunciation and looted icons, holy vessels and the tomb in the church.

Orthodox religious monuments in Turkey and the occupied northern sector of Cyprus are constantly being looted and no‐one has ever been arrested at any time. Will the Council, therefore, take account of this widespread phenomenon and take steps to ensure that the Turkish authorities assume their responsibilities?

Answer

The Council notes that under the Treaty of Peace, signed at Lausanne in July 1923, the Turkish Government undertook to grant full protection to the churches, synagogues, cemeteries, and other religious establishments of non‐Moslem minorities.

The European Council meeting in Luxembourg on 12‐13 December 1997 again underlined the necessity for the Turkish Government to meet its fundamental obligations in the field of democracy and human rights. It recalled, in line with the council position expressed at the Association Council with Turkey on 29 April 1997, that strengthening Turkey's links with the European Union also depends on that country's pursuit of political and economic reforms, including respect for and protection of minorities.

The situation of democracy and human rights in Turkey remains high on the Council's agenda. These issues are brought up virtually in all meetings with the Turkish authorities.

Question No 53 by Liam Hyland (H−0141/98)

Subject: On increasing the demand for milk and milk products

Over the coming years, milk production in the EU is expected to decline, while demand for cheese and fresh products is expected to increase.

What proposals would the Council support to halt the decline in milk production and to increase the consumption of milk products?

Answer

In the present market situation in the dairy sector there is a structural surplus production of the order of 9 million tonnes of milk on a total quota of 115, 5 million tonnes, so there is no question of shortage in fresh milk to produce the increasing amount of certain export products like cheese.

The Council, within the framework of the Commission proposals ‚Agenda 2000’, expected to be presented in March of this year and on which the European Parliament will be called to give an opinion, will examine the functioning of the milk CMO and will decide on its future as well as on possible adaptations.

Question No 54 by Niall Andrews (H−0143/98)

Subject: EUROPOL

Under Article 2 of the EUROPOL Convention, the Council can decide to deal with forms of crime other than those set out in that article. This means that EUROPOL could deal with murder cases, illicit trafficking in cultural goods, counterfeiting, piracy, forgery, environmental and computer crime.

What is the view of the UK Presidency on this option?

Answer

In reply to the question put by the Honourable Member I wish to state that the question relating to the extension of the role of EUROPOL has not, up to now, been the subject of a discussion in the Council. In addition, I would like to say that the Council has not received any proposal to consider the matter.

Question No 55 by Ioannis Theonas (H−0151/98)

Subject: Financial market crisis in southern Asia

The recent crisis in southern Asia has caused particular concern in financial circles and among US multinationals in that they believe that the full impact of the crisis has not yet begun to make itself felt, despite the clear fall in profits and the disruption of monetary stability. Commissioner de Silguy tried to reassure public opinion but acknowledged that no‐one could know the extent of the impact on the European economy and the monetary/financial system.

Given that all the adverse repercussions at both monetary and financial level will be borne by working people, who will be called on to pay for the crisis once again by taking a cut in their living standards, will the Council say whether it shares the Commission's views and what initiatives it intends to take, bearing in mind the imminent need to select which countries will take part in the 'euro', which will intensify pressure of a speculative and other nature on the monetary system, particularly for those countries excluded from the third stage of EMU?

Answer

The (Ecofin) Council discussed the Asian financial crisis informally over lunch on its 19 January 1998 session.

Ecofin Ministers met Mr Camdessus, IMF Managing Director, on 16 February to exchange views on the assessment of the situation and on ways to respond to the crisis and restore confidence. They agreed that the impact of the Asian situation on Europe's economies would be material but manageable.

European economic interests in Asia are high: exports from the EU to the region are greater than those from the U.S.; the exposure of European banks is greater than the sum of United States and Japanese exposure.

For this reason the EU members:

‐  have been giving full support to the IMF's action in seeking to restore confidence in the region, including exceptionally large calls on IMF finance.
As major shareholders, EU members are ultimately responsible for a significant proportion of the resources committed by the IMF and World Bank;

‐  have played an active role in getting agreement to the new IMF Supplemental Reserve Facility;

‐  have encouraged EU commercial banks to play an important and positive role in the current global efforts to secure continued rollovers of Korean banking debts;

‐  have provided 7 of the 13 bilateral contributions to Korea's second line of defence.

Question No 56 by Inger Schörling (H−0154/98)

Subject: Trade union rights

At the request of the European Council Summit Meeting in Amsterdam, the Commission has drawn up a proposal for a Council Regulation introducing an intervention mechanism for the Commission to remove certain obstacles to trade.

The aim is to secure freedom of movement for goods within the internal market, which is one of the Community's fundamental principles. So as to prevent infringements of the principle of freedom of movement, which may arise through requiring licences or technical certificates, stopping products by obstructing transport on motorways, at airports or ports, for instance, the Commission wishes to be able to intervene quickly and request Member States to take measures to remove the obstacles. Member States will have between three and five days to submit their views. If a Member State does not comply with the Commission's decisions, the Commission may take the matter further to the Court of Justice.

The EU has no jurisdiction in this area and the Regulation is proposed on the basis of Article 235.

Does the proposal imply that the Commission can force Member States to intervene in strikes and lockouts? The trade unions are highly critical of EU interference with fundamental trade union rights and intervention in trade union disputes. Does the proposal not jeopardize dialogue between the two sides of industry? How will the right to strike be guaranteed?

Answer

The Council wants to draw the attention of the Honourable Parlamentarian to the fact that to this date the Commission proposal has only been presented to the relevant Working Party of the Internal Market Council. On this occasion the representative of the Commission, at the request of a number of Member State delegations, underlined that it was not the intention of the Commission to restrict the right to strike. This is also expressly mentioned in the Explanatory Memorandum accompanying the draft Regulation.

Against this background, and since no discussion on substance has yet taken place within the auspices of the Council, it is not possible for the Council to express any opinion on the Commission proposal at this stage.

Question No 57 by Mark Killilea (H−0158/98)

Subject: Amended merger regulation

One of the stated aims of the UK Presidency is the creation of a more effective single market, in particular the simplification of legislation and rules pertaining to it. Will the Council comment on recent criticisms of the European Commission by UNICE, the Union of Industrial and Employers Confederations of Europe, for their proposed changes to the Merger Regulation 4064/89(3) which they say go far beyond what is necessary, and which will impose excessive costs in terms of time and money on companies?

Answer

The Council draws the attention of the Honourable Member of the Parliament to the fact that the comments of UNICE, the Union of Industrial and Employers' Confederation of Europe, do not refer to amendments to the Council Regulation (EEC) no 4064/89 on the control of concentrations between undertakings, but concern amendments to the Commission Regulation (EC) no 3384/94, which implements the afore‐mentioned Council Regulation.

As a consequence, the Council considers it not appropriate to comment on observations which do not refer to one of its own legislative acts but to a Commission Regulation.

Question No 58 by Richard Corbett (H−0979/97)

Subject: Denomination of euro notes

Can the Council explain why it saw fit to provide for notes of 500 euro? Is it not aware that such large denominations are of little use to the wider public, but extremely useful to those dealing in the informal or unofficial economy, including drug dealers?

Answer

In conformity with the allocation of competences under the Treaty, the European Central Bank (ECB) will have an exclusive competence on matters relating to the issue of euro banknotes, such as denominations, technical specifications and design (Article 105a of the Treaty and Article 16 of the Protocol on the Statutes of the European System of Central Banks and the European Central Bank).

The decisions of the ECB on these matters are prepared by the European Monetary Institute in accordance with Article 109f paragraph 3 of the Treaty and will be adopted by the ECB once it has been established.

The question raised by the Honourable Parliamentarian thus does not fall within the competence of the Council.

Question No 59 by Bernd Posselt (H−1013/97)

Subject: Trade and cooperation agreement with Croatia

In April and on 10 November 1997, the Council set out its position on extending the Phare programme to include Croatia and on opening negotiations on a trade and cooperation agreement. What criteria did it establish, and does it see any prospect for at last beginning talks with Croatia on a trade and cooperation agreement, since Croatia respects human rights, is a democratic country subject to the rule of law and, unlike most EU Member States, has ratified the Council of Europe's convention on minorities and its charter on minority languages?

Answer

The Honourable Parliamentarian is reminded that the relations between the European Union and those countries of South Eastern Europe without Association Agreements are covered by the conditionality strategy. The conditions applicable to different levels of relations and cooperation, as well as the different criteria for evaluating compliance, are laid down in the conclusions of the General Affairs Council of 29 April 1997. On the basis of these criteria, the Council regularly monitors and evaluates the progress made in meeting the conditionality requirements.

On 10 November 1997, while noting that there had been some progress, the Council concluded that Croatia had not complied with all the obligations arising from the Dayton/Paris and Erdut Agreements. Any improvement of relations, including the extension of the Phare programme and the possible beginning of talks on a trade and cooperation agreement referred to by the Honourable Parliamentarian, will therefore depend on further efforts by Croatia.

II. Questions to the Commission

 

Question No 71 by Hugh McMahon (H−0067/98)

Subject: EU Bathing Water Directive

What discussions has the Commission had with the UK Government with a view to increasing the number of designated beaches protected under the Bathing Water Directive, and does the Commission have any plans to revise this legislation?

Answer

The Commission takes note of the concerns of the honourable Member about the number of identified bathing areas in the UK, and about the revision of the existing Community legislation.

The identification of bathing water areas under the current Bathing Water Quality Directive 76/160/EEC is for the Member States. The Directive describes bathing areas in Article 1.2 as: ’All running or still fresh waters or parts thereof and sea water, in which a) bathing is explicitly authorized by the competent authorities of each Member State, or b) bathing is not prohibited and is traditionally practised by a large number of bathers.’. It is in particular this last phrase (traditionally practised by a LARGE NUMBER of bathers) that leaves considerable room for interpretation. The Commission believes that the local authorities are the best placed bodies to judge this and does therefore not interfere in the actual identification of those zones. Moreover, the Commission does not have, for the moment, the resources to control these identifications. The Commission only questions the identification or non‐identification of certain bathing areas if it receives convincing information about bathing activities, as described under the Directive, in particular from concerned citizens or local action groups.

It must be noted that the number of identified bathing areas throughout the European Union, including in the UK, increases every year. In the UK, where only coastal areas have been identified, the number has increased from 455 in 1992 to 486 in 1997. The Commission regrets, and has said so for many years at the presentation of its annual Bathing Water Quality report, that the UK has not identified inland bathing areas.

As the revision of the existing legislation is concerned, the Commission's amended proposal for the revision of the Directive on bathing water quality is now ready for discussion in Council pursuant to Article 189 (a) §2 of the EC Treaty. The Commission has on several occasions requested upcoming presidencies of the Council, including the present UK presidency, to take the proposal up in their agenda for discussion. The different presidencies have so far not given an indication that they will indeed discuss this proposal.

Question No 72 by Nuala Ahern (H−0083/98)

Subject: Proposals by BNFL to increase radioactive discharges from the Sellafield plant

What information has the Commission received from the United Kingdom authorities concerning BNFL proposals to increase the radioactive discharges from the Sellafield plant currently under assessment by the UK Environment Agency?

Question No 73 by James Fitzsimons (H−0139/98)

Subject: Authorization for increased discharges into the air at Sellafield and further nuclear leaks at Sellafield

As the Commission is no doubt aware BNFL has initiated a consultation process concerning proposed changes to radioactive discharge limits at its Sellafield plant. It has applied for authorization to increase discharges into the air and to decrease but not eliminate discharges into the sea. In the light of yet another nuclear leak at Sellafield and my concern about the operations of Sellafield, which have been on the record for well over a decade, will the Commission, once and for all, intervene in this affair, and support the demands of those who have been seeking the closure of the Sellafield plant?

Joint Answer

Discharges from nuclear sites are regulated within strict authorizations issued by national competent authorities. Such authorizations ensure that resultant doses to members of the public not only comply with the Community Basic Safety Standards for the protection of the health of workers and the general public against the dangers arising from ionizing radiation but also that such doses are as low as reasonably achievable, the so‐called ALARA principle. It is the responsibility of Member States to ensure compliance with the Basic Safety Standards and so the revision of authorizations for the discharge of radioactive waste is a matter of national competence.

Even though there is no obligation to do so, the Commission was informed by the United Kingdom authorities that a proposal to vary the Sellafield site authorizations was being considered by the competent authorities and was to go to public consultation at the end of January 1998. the Commission has received a copy of the papers prepared for public consultation and will continue to follow these matters closely.

The Commission is aware of recent reports of an incident at the Sellafield site on 28 January 1998 in which two workers came into contact with radioactive dust. BNFL is investigating the incident in parallel with the United Kingdom authorities and the results of the investigation are to be published. The incident has been temporarily classified as Level One, the lowest level on the International Nuclear Event Scale of One to Seven. The Commission understands that there was no release of radioactivity into the environment. Consequently, no member of the public was at risk.

As guardians of the Euratom Treaty, the Commission would intervene only if there was evidence that the United Kingdom was not enforcing its responsibilities under that Treaty. The Commission has no basis, therefore, for action of the type proposed.

Question No 74 by Carmen Díez de Rivera Icaza (H−0101/98)

Subject: Funicular railway inside the Picos de Europa National Park

Is the Commission aware of the decision taken in Spain by the Asturias regional government concerning the forthcoming construction of a funicular railway inside the Picos de Europa National Park in order to provide access to the town of Bulnes? In the Commission's view, does this constitute compliance with Directive 92/43/EEC on the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora(4) , Directive 79/409/EEC on the conservation of wild birds(5) and Directive 85/337/EEC on environmental impact assessment(6) ?

Answer

The Commission's attention has already been drawn to certain projects, which could affect the ‚Picos de Europa’ national park, in written question 2506/97 by Mrs González Álvarez and others.

The Commission would like to say that the Spanish authorities have classified part of the national park as a Special Protection Area for birds, in accordance with Article 4 of Council Directive 79/409/EEC of 2 April 1979 on the conservation of wild birds(7) . The official name of the Special Protection Area is ‚Montaña de Covadonga’.

Having said this, it is necessary to point out that although the village of Bulnes is nearby, it is not situated within the ‚Montaña de Covadonga’ Special Protection Area. The Commission does not have any information to suggest that the funicular railway project is likely to be harmful to the Special Protection Area.

On the other hand, the village of Bulnes is situated in an area Spain proposes to include in the Natura 2000 network, under Council Directive 92/43/EEC of 21 May 1992 on the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora(8) .

According to paragraphs 2, 3 and 4 of Article 6 of Directive 92/43/EEC, Member States must take the appropriate steps to prevent the deterioration of natural habitats and habitats of species, and to prevent the disturbance of species for which the areas have been designated, inasmuch as such disturbances are likely to have a significant effect on the objectives of the directive.

The above‐mentioned provisions will not be applicable however until the list of sites of Community importance constituting a coherent ecological network of special areas of conservation called ‚Natura 2000’ is established by the Commission.

Furthermore, funicular railways are not listed in the categories of projects, for which environmental impact assessment is obligatory according to Directive 85/337/EEC on environmental impact assessment(9) .

Nevertheless, the Commission has contacted the Spanish authorities to ask them to adopt the necessary measures to ensure that the project is not harmful to the environment.

Question No 77 by Ole Krarup (H−0014/98)

Subject: EIB loan for the construction of the A4 motorway in Poland

It is astonishing that projects designed to connect eastern and central Europe to the TENs and partly financed by the EIB disregard their adverse impact on the environment and health.

For example, the planned A4 motorway in Poland, part of the TENs extension scheme, will cut through the centre of the heavily polluted city of Katowice in Silesia, and its route will also affect some of the last remaining recreational areas in Upper Silesia as well as pass 100 m from a recently built housing estate which has some 10 000 residents.

The EIB has not been very open about a number of TENs projects in eastern and central Europe. Members of the CEE‐Bankwatch Network have sought in vain to have specific environmental impact analyses carried out for various infrastructure projects in respect of which the EIB has granted loans, and their organization has, for instance, had far more fruitful dialogue with both the World Bank and the ERBD.

What steps will the Commission take to safeguard the interests of the public in eastern and central Europe in ensuring that environmental factors are taken into account when the EIB grants loans for infrastructure projects?

Answer

The Government of Poland has embarked on an ambitious investment programme for the construction of approximately 2600 km of toll motorways to be built over the next twenty years. Co‐financing from Phare and the International Financing Institutions is provided to support this programme.

It goes without saying that all construction will take full account of the need to protect, and where possible, to improve the environment. The Commission feels that the Polish Government has adequate legal safeguards to assess the environmental impact(10) .

In particular you should note that full environmental impact assessments are carried out prior to the decision on the location of motorways and, therefore, prior to the provision of EIB loans and Phare co‐financing. In the case of A4‐motorway, the decision on its route through the agglomeration of Katowice was based on a wide consultation of all relevant bodies. It needs to be underlined that the motorway will not cross the city centre of Katowice but will by‐pass it. Therefore, it will improve the environment, the circulation and the road safety in the city centre by diverting the traffic from it. In addition, since Katowice is a densely populated area, the construction of the motorway will naturally include environmental protection facilities including noise barriers and the drainage of surface water in conformity with the environmental standards required for city areas.

Where Phare co‐financing is provided, the Commission carefully examines the environmental impact reports for such works prior to taking any funding decision. This is currently even more important given that major investments in infrastructure, notably transport and environment, have been defined as priorities for the pre‐accession strategy. In conclusion, you should note that the draft Accession Partnership puts a special emphasis on transposing all environmental directives.

With regard to the involvement of EIB in the motorway construction programme, the Commission has proposed the same approach thus requiring the beneficiary to provide the necessary environmental impact assessment as a pre‐condition for the decision on a loan.

Question No 78 by Nikitas Kaklamanis (H−0023/98)

Subject: Savage murder and arson attack against a chapel in Istanbul

On 12 January, a number of unknown persons entered the chapel of Aghios Therapontos in Istanbul which harbours the well with the holy water, savagely murdered the guardian of the chapel and the holy well and threw the corpse down the well.

They then set fire to the chapel and stole the icons and the holy vessels, as the Turkish Police who found the corpse of the murdered guard later confirmed.

This is the second such incident and follows the bomb attack against the Oecumenical Patriarchate in Istanbul a short time ago, which illustrates the steadily escalating acts of provocation by Turks against the Greek minority and against the Churches and ecclesiastical monuments and confirms that all these terrorist actions take place with the undoubted connivance of the Turkish authorities, if not with their active encouragement.

Does the Commission intend to impress on Turkey, a country bound by an association agreement with the European Union, not by words and pious wishes but by very specific actions, the need to respect its international obligations, and notably to protect its minorities in general and to respect religious relics and holy places?

Answer

The Commission deplores the serious incident against the Greek Orthodox Church of St. Therapontos in Istanbul, last January. The Turkish authorities have started an investigation. The initial information obtained appears to indicate that this was a criminal act, its main motive being the theft of valuables.

In all contacts with the Turkish authorities, the Commission emphasizes the importance of improving the human rights situation and continuing the democratization process in Turkey. Despite Ankara's recent decision to suspend the political dialogue with the European Union for the time being, the Commission intends to continue to make its concern known to its interlocutors with regard to these issues.

The European Council held in Luxembourg in December 1997 reiterated that the strengthening of the links between Turkey and the European Union was also dependent upon the continuation of the political and economic reforms Turkey has started to introduce, particularly in terms of bringing human rights standards and practices in Turkey into line without those in the European Union. The Council added that it is also dependent upon the respect and protection of minorities.

Question No 79 by Konstantinos Hatzidakis (H−0028/98)

Subject: Progress of pre‐accession negotiations on Cyprus

Pre‐accession negotiations between the European Union and Cyprus are due to begin on 30 March 1998. It has been repeatedly stressed that accession must benefit both communities on the island. Given that it has been decided to launch an information campaign concerning the benefits to be expected from the accession of the whole of Cyprus to the European Union, will the Commission say what specific measures have been taken so far in this connection and what other actions it intends to take in the immediate future? Given also that the Turkish‐Cypriot leader, Rauf Denktash, recently prohibited Turkish Cypriots from taking part in meetings of groups seeking to bring about a rapprochement between the two communities, can the Commission say whether it intends to take steps to have this ban lifted?

Answer

The General Affairs Council of 6 March 1995 invited the Commission to undertake an information strategy in consultation with the Cypriot Government, towards the Turkish Cypriot community in order to explain the advantages it could derive from accession to the European Community.

Since then, the Commission has supported a wide range of information activities involving an important number of members of the Turkish Cypriot civil society, both inside and outside Cyprus.

These activities include frequent conferences, debates and contacts promoted by the Delegation of the Commission in Nicosia with Turkish Cypriot academic, trade‐union, press and business circles.

Bi‐communal meetings have been actively encouraged in the island and several bi‐communal groups of young businessmen and journalists have visited institutions in Brussels in the last years.

Turkish Cypriots have also participated in a seminar on Community policies and institutions in the European Institute of Public Administration in Maastricht. The Commission has strongly supported the work of Cypriot women from both communities towards peace which resulted in March last year in a conference held in Brussels under the title ‚Women speak out: give peace a chance’. There have also been several information activities addressed towards the important Cypriot community in Great Britain.

Besides all these events, the Commission delegation in Cyprus distributes once a month a newsletter to different opinion relays in the north of Cyprus and has made available translations into Turkish of Community information brochures dealing with the main Community policies, decision‐making procedures and institutions.

The Commission is aware of recent difficulties concerning the continuation of bi‐communal meetings and continues to impress on all partners concerned the need to pursue these contacts in order to improve mutual trust and confidence.

Question No 80 by Sören Wibe (H−0031/98)

Subject: Kurdish refugees from Turkey

In view of the situation that has arisen after a number of Kurdish refugees recently reached Italy, will the Commission say whether it is having talks with the Turkish government about what is causing those refugees to try to get into EU Member States?

Has it pointed out to the Turkish government that, in the long term, it is not tougher border controls but only greater respect for human rights, e.g. respect for the Kurdish minority's liberties and rights in Turkey, that will stem the tide of refugees?

Answer

The recent influx of people from Iraq, Turkey and neighbouring areas is not a new phenomenon. For several years, Member States have accepted and are continuing to accept several thousand people from those regions.

In 1995, the Commission proposed to establish cooperation between the European Union and Turkey in the fields of justice and home affairs. The Association Council therefore set up an institutional framework in the same year. It provides in particular for regular meetings within the scope of the K4 Committee, composed of senior officials and ministers. Political reasons have prevented the implementation of this system.

Furthermore, the communication of 15 July 1997 on the future of relations with Turkey, whose substance was approved by the Luxembourg European Council, provides for the financing of cooperation in the field of justice and home affairs, with regard to immigration and the prevention of organized crime, in particular. These activities will fall within the scope of the Community budget, either under the MEDA programme, or by means of special financial cooperation amounting to ECU 375 million, when the Council has approved it.

The recent influx has many complicated causes. Further analysis is necessary. With regard to the influx of people from Turkey, although their decisions may also have been based on economic reasons, it is certain that the long‐term conflict in south‐east Turkey has contributed towards the movements of the population and the deterioration of the economic situation in the area.

The Luxembourg European Council asked for a plan of action to be prepared in order to find a solution to this problem. The General Affairs Council approved the plan on 26 January. Detailed analysis of the causes of the recent influx is one of the actions to be implemented. The plan of action also provides for discussions to be held between the Presidency and the Commission, and the Turkish authorities.

The plan of action includes measures relating to the first and second pillars (detailed study of causes, contacts with Turkey, humanitarian aid in the region) and measures relating to the third pillar, with regard to the right of asylum, the implementation of the Dublin Convention, the prevention of illegal immigration and police cooperation against illegal immigration channels.

In Agenda 2000, the Commission emphasized the need for a civilian rather than a military solution to the problems in south‐east Turkey. The Luxembourg European Council stated that the strengthening of the links between Turkey and the European Union is also dependent upon the respect and protection of minorities.

The economic and social situation in south‐east Turkey must also be improved if we wish to prevent an increase in the number of immigrants from that region. Funds are available under the MEDA programme to implement development projects in the region. To enable the funds for such actions to be released, the European Parliament's cooperation is of course very important. The Commission hopes that the problems which have so far arisen with Parliament on this subject can be resolved.

Question No 81 by Maj Theorin (H−0046/98)

Subject: Turkey

Amnesty International's report for 1997 and the US Congress' report for the same year reveal an alarming human rights situation in Turkey in terms both of summary executions and the number of people who have disappeared,

In early 1998, many people are fleeing from Turkey to the EU. The EU has exerted strong pressure on Turkey to halt the flow of refugees and Turkey has now arrested suspected refugees en masse.

Does the Commissioner consider that there is a link between human rights shortcomings and the Kurdish refugees fleeing Turkey? Is it consistent to criticize Turkey for not satisfying human rights criteria while refugees from Turkey are not given shelter in Europe?

Answer

With regard to the recent influx of people from Turkey, although their decisions may also have been based on economic reasons, it is certain that the long‐term conflict in south‐east Turkey has contributed towards the movements of the population and the deterioration of the economic situation in the area.

Italy has been particularly affected by the recent influx. During the urgent debate organized on this subject by the European Parliament on 14 January, the member of the Commission responsible for relations with Turkey congratulated the Italian authorities' on their attitude to this matter. They reacted to the problem in a humanitarian manner, whilst ensuring full compliance with the conventions to which Italy is a party.

The Luxembourg European Council asked that a plan of action be prepared by the Council in order to find a solution to this problem. The General Affairs Council approved the plan on 26 January. It proposes measures within the framework of the second and first pillars, as well as the third pillar.

The plan of action includes measures relating to the detailed study of causes of the influx of refugees, contacts with the Turkish authorities, humanitarian aid in the region, the right of asylum, the implementation of the Dublin Convention, the prevention of illegal immigration and police cooperation against illegal immigration channels.

In Agenda 2000, the Commission considered the problem of south‐east Turkey and emphasized the need for a civilian rather than a military solution to the problems in that region. The Luxembourg European Council also stated that the strengthening of the links between Turkey and the European Union is also dependent upon the respect and protection of minorities.

The economic and social situation in south‐east Turkey must also be improved if we wish to prevent a long term increase in the number of immigrants from that region. Funds are available under the MEDA programme to implement development projects in the region. To enable the funds for such actions to be released, the European Parliament's cooperation is of course very important. The Commission hopes that the problems which have so far arisen with Parliament on this subject can be resolved.

Question No 82 by Hans Lindqvist (H−0064/98)

Subject: The Turkish army's campaign against the Kurds

Turkey has repeatedly used a variety of threats in its attempts to gain the upper hand in its talks with the EU on possible EU membership. On the occasion of the Luxembourg Summit before Christmas Turkey threatened to withdraw its application for membership if it was not offered negotiations on the same terms as Cyprus. The Luxembourg European Council asked that a plan of action be prepared by the Council in order to find a solution to this problem. The General Affairs Council approved the plan on 26 January. It proposes measures within the framework of the second and first pillars, as well as the third pillar.

In Agenda 2000, the Commission considered the problem of south‐east Turkey and emphasized the need for a civilian rather than a military solution in that region. The Luxembourg European Council also stated that the strengthening of the links between Turkey and the European Union is also dependent upon the respect and protection of minorities.

The economic and social situation in south‐east Turkey must also be improved if we wish to prevent a long term increase in the number of immigrants from that region. Funds are available under the MEDA programme to implement development projects in the region. To enable the funds for such actions to be released, the European Parliament's cooperation is of course very important. The Commission hopes that the problems which have so far arisen with Parliament on this subject can be resolved.

Question No 83 by Jan Andersson (H−0063/98)

Subject: Enlargement

Financial crime and drug trafficking are an increasing problem in many applicant countries.

What preparations has the Commission been making as regards contacts and strategies for continuing its efforts to deal with these problems?

Answer

The Commission shares the view that economic crime and drug trafficking are a serious problem in central and eastern Europe.

The Commission fully supports the implementation of the action plan to combat organized crime approved by the European Council of Amsterdam, and the proposed pre‐accession pact on cooperation against crime with the candidate countries.

In the framework of the enhanced pre‐accession strategy and the Accession Partnerships support will be given to: institution building, including legislation and training of law enforcement bodies, justice, police and border management; anti‐money laundering measures; the fight against corruption.

In cooperation with international organizations like UNDCP and the Council of Europe, the Commission has an integrated strategy aimed at supply and demand reduction and institution building, in particular in the field of customs, and police and interregional cooperation. Major projects deal with the strengthening of drug law enforcement capabilities in southeastern Europe, and the supply reduction of synthetic drugs.

Question No 84 by Doeke Eisma (H−0081/98)

Subject: Priorities for environmental legislation in central and eastern Europe

In paragraph 86 of its resolution (A4‐0368/97)(11) on 'Agenda 2000', Parliament called on the Commission to establish a list, in cooperation with the Council and Parliament, of the most important elements of EU environmental legislation outside the internal market which applicant countries must satisfy at the time of accession. This increases the political pressure to invest more in the environment.

Can the Commission say what stage it has reached in establishing this list, and when Parliament can expect to see a proposal?

Answer

Full adaptation of candidate countries to the Community environmental acquis is an essential element in the accession process. Given the overall environmental situation in these countries, the financial and administrative effort for the adoption of the acquis will be considerable. Hence the importance of setting up priorities which will allow both the candidate countries to focus their efforts and the... to organize increased assistance.

The ‚Accession Partnerships’, presently under preparation, outline the key short‐ and medium‐term priorities in environment for the pre‐accession period on the basis of the findings of the Opinions. (Parliament has already been informed on the principles, priorities, intermediate objectives and conditions of the Partnerships which are currently being approved by the Council)(12) .

Natural environmental strategies based on the Accession Partnerships will be further elaborated in the ‚National Programmes for the Adoption of the Acquis’. These will be finalized by the candidate countries during 1998, in consultation with the Commission. The Commission has already produced a ‚Guide to the Approximation of EU Environmental Legislation’(13) which has been sent to Parliament and which presents applicant countries with an appropriate methodology. In addition, the Commission is preparing a Communication where it will set out what has been achieved and what remains to be achieved in the accession process in the field of environment, and make relevant proposals.(14)

Question No 85 by Karl Habsburg‐Lothringen (H−0099/98)

Subject: Names of units in DG IA
