Does the Commission realize that, as well as amounting to gross ignorance of historical and cultural reality, such a decision would be bound to entail adverse political consequences, especially since Croatia has never been part of the Balkans, but is a Central European country whose fundamental sympathies have always lain with the West?

Answer

No, there is no unit in the Commission named ‚West Balkans’.

Question No 86 by Mair Morgan (H−0002/98)

Subject: Child labour

What measures has the Commission taken to ensure that child labour, particularly bonded child labour has not been used in the production of carpets, clothes, footwear and other manufactured goods imported into the European Union from the Indian subcontinent?

Answer

1.  The latest co‐operation agreements signed with countries of South Asia (currently India, Sri Lanka, Nepal) include a Human Right clause, giving the possibility to the Commission to raise this issue with partners and eventually to take, if necessary, appropriate measures.

2.  In the framework of the revised Community's scheme of generalized tariff preferences (GSP), laid down in Regulations (EC) No 3281/94 and (EC) 1256/96(15) the Council has adopted provisions in favour of the elimination of child labour. Pursuant to the aforementioned Regulations the preferential treatment may be temporarily withdrawn from beneficiary countries in the case of bonded labour either of adults or children (Article 9).

It has also adopted the principle of a social incentive regime (Article 7) to be put into operation in 1998. Under this new initiative scheme, additional preferences may be granted, on their request, to countries which have adopted and are effectively enforcing the substance of international standards established by the International Labour Organization (ILO). Those relate, on the one hand, to the rights of workers to organize and bargain collectively (ILO Conventions Nos 87 and 98) and, on the other hand, to the minimum age for admission to employment (ILO Convention No 138). The Council is currently discussing the proposal adopted by the Commission in October 1997 which sets out the intensity and the modalities for implementing this special incentive arrangement.

3.  Other measures include activities aimed at the elimination of child labour/bonded labour. In this context the Commission is launching a development aid project in collaboration with the ILO, which will supplement the ILO's efforts in Pakistan within the scope of its International Programme for the Elimination of Child Labour.

Question No 87 by Jaak Vandemeulebroucke (H−0003/98)

Subject: Language use in the Official Journal

The Official Journal L328 of 28 November 1997 contains a list of the authorities subject to the agreement on public contracts. On page 10 for Belgium there is a list only in the French language.

The Commission is aware of my concern with regard to the use of languages. Can it indicate why this list was included only in French? Should it be assumed that the Dutch and German speakers are not subject to this legislation on tenders?

Answer

The question posed by the Honourable Member appears to seek an answer to the question why Annex 1 to European Parliament and Council Directive 97/52/EC, published in the Official Journal L 328 of 28 November 1997 lists the Belgian authorities in the French language only and to the question whether it should be assumed, in the absence of a list of Belgian authorities in the Dutch and German languages, that the Dutch and German speakers are not subject to this legislation.

The reason for publishing the list of Belgian authorities in French only.

European Parliament and Council Directive 97/52/EC has been adopted to adapt existing Community legislation in the field of public procurement(16) to the Agreement on Government Procurement, concluded at the end of the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations, on April 15, 1994. Annex 1 to this Agreement lists the contracting authorities which will procure in accordance with the provisions of the Agreement. The Agreement on Government Procurement has three official languages, English, French and Spanish. Therefore, all States had to provide their contribution to the annexes in, at least, one of these official languages. Belgium provided its contribution for Annex 1 to the Agreement in French. The annexes have been approved as such by the States Parties to the Agreement and are now an integral part of the Agreement on Government Procurement.

European Parliament and Council Directive 97/52/EC contains in its Annex 1 the list of contracting authorities as they were approved for the Agreement on Government Procurement.

The presumption that, in the absence of a Dutch and German version of Annex 1, Dutch and German speakers are not subject to this legislation.

The Commission kindly reminds the Honourable Member of the fact that a directive is not addressed to individual persons, but to the Member States. The Member States are bound to implement, within the time period provided for by the directive, the directive in their national legislation. The Belgian authorities are therefore entitled to take the necessary steps that their national constitution or legislation requires in order to respect the use of the languages in their country.

Moreover, as a general rule, the question whether or not someone, contracting authority or interested company, is subject to the national legislation implementing Community directives, does not depend on the language that person speaks, but on the contents of that legislation.

Question No 88 by María Izquierdo Rojo (H−0010/98)

Subject: Violence against women

The European Parliament recently adopted a resolution on the need to establish a European Union wide campaign for zero tolerance of violence against women(17) .

In the light of this resolution and given the need to uphold women's right to life as part of efforts to safeguard human rights and combat this invisible crime effectively:

When and how will the Commission launch European campaigns to combat violence against women? What timetable has it drawn up for such campaigns? Given the social costs of violence against women in terms of spending on social security, health care, legal costs, education, etc., will it seek to make those responsible for violence against women contribute in some way to the funding necessary to implement this policy designed to protect women?

Answer

1.  The Commission fully shares the Honourable Member's concern on the need to effectively combat violence against women.

It is already focusing on this problem, particularly by means of the DAPHNE Initiative which supports several relevant projects, for example that of the European Women's Lobby creating a European Observatory on Violence against Women, and a research project by Crime Concern UK into methods of preventing domestic violence against women.

2.  The Commission takes the view that a European campaign to combat such violence against women can only be effective if it has an assured budget. Although the 1998 budget line for the DAPHNE Initiative contains funding for measures to prepare for the 1999 European Year against Violence against Women, the Parliament has not yet made available funds for the Year itself. Such funds could only be included in the 1999 budget and by the time it is adopted in December 1998 it will be too late to make the necessary commitments and arrangements for 1999. In these circumstances, the Commission is proposing to designate 8 March 1999 (International Women's Day) as a day against violence against women and to mark it as such by holding a suitable event.

This event might take the form of a conference or a seminar. The Commission will in any case discuss this matter with the appropriate bodies in the Parliament, not least with the Women's Rights Committee.

3.  The Commission is aware of the costs of violence not merely to the victims themselves but to society as a whole, both in financial and social terms Certain financial costs are recoverable from the perpetrators in criminal or civil proceedings before national courts or tribunals, but compensation and recovery of costs is a matter for complainants to raise according to the rules of the individual Member States.

As regards the social and emotional costs, not merely do these fall on the victims and their families but also on the social and support services of the Member States themselves. The recovery of such costs by the Member States can only be a matter for the State concerned.

Question No 89 by David Martin (H−0012/98)

Subject: Non‐compliance of high voltage (HV) switchgear and controlgear

It has been brought to my attention that suppliers of high voltage switchgear and controlgear are being allowed to continue supplying apparatus that is non‐compliant with the requirements of the EMC Directive 89/336/EEC(18) which was fully implemented on 1 January 1996, and at variance with the latest Guidelines On The Application Of Council Directive 89/336/EEC of May 1989 On The Approximation Of The Laws Of The Member States Relating To Electromagnetic Compatibility. Can the Commission outline what action it will take to make sure Directive 89/336/EEC is complied with?

Answer

To date, the Commission has not received any specific evidence or formal complaints about cases of non‐compliance in the application of the EMC Directive to ‚high voltage switchgear and controlgear’.

The devices considered must indeed be deemed to be covered by the EMC Directive, unless it can be demonstrated that they are not liable to cause electromagnetic disturbance.

The Electromagnetic Compatibility (EMC) Directive, applies in fact to all electric and electronic appliances together with equipment and installations containing electric or electronic components, provided they are liable to cause electromagnetic disturbance, or to be affected by such disturbance.

Inclusion or exclusion of specific equipment must be determined not only taking into account their characteristics, but also the way in which they are intended to be operated and their expected electromagnetic environment. The Commission has recently published a Guide, which includes amongst other things, criteria for determining which apparatus is excluded from the application of the Directive.

In order to give a more complete answer on the issue, the Commission would need more detailed information. In particular, the type of equipment considered, its EMC characteristics and where, why and by whom it has been placed on the market in spite of not being in compliance with the Directive.

The Guide on the application of the EMC Directive does in fact mention among the exclusions from its scope, protection equipment like circuit breakers without electronic parts, or components which are electromagnetically active and which only produce disturbance of very short duration. Manual switches that are not EMC active may also be excluded. However, it is not possible without further details to conclude that the devices in question might fall within those categories.

The Commission is fully prepared to enquire and examine the issue further as soon as it will get more precise information.

Question No 90 by Mark Watts (H−0013/98)

Subject: Slaughter of sheep in France for Eid‐El‐Kabir festival

In April 1997 the mass ritual slaughter of sheep in France caused enormous public outrage. Last September, responding to Oral Question No 90 H−0613/97(19) , the Commissioner informed me that the Commission cannot accept that those infringements of Community legislation should be permitted to continue, and that it seemed reasonable to ask the French authorities to confirm that in future the festival will be organized according to the Community legislation concerned. He promised: 'If the French authorities fail to provide adequate guarantees concerning future compliance with Community law in this respect, the Commission will consider the opening of the infringement procedure provided for under Article 169 of the EC Treaty.' What guarantees has the Commission now obtained, and can it reassure me that this abhorrent barbarism will not be allowed to take place this year?

Answer

The Commission has intervened further with the French authorities stressing that although directive 93/119/EC permits religious slaughter of animals, neither the directive nor the relevant Community public and animal health rules allow such slaughter to be carried out in the open air or other places outside slaughterhouses.

France has, in consequence, been requested to confirm that it will take the necessary action to ensure that the relevant provisions of Community law will in future be respected.

The Commission will monitor carefully any reports it receives of breaches of the relevant rules during this year's celebrations of the festival in question.

The Commission is conscious of the fact that this is a sensitive issue involving the religious and cultural traditions of certain ethnic minorities. However, given the information it has obtained about the arrangements made in other Member States also having minority populations sharing the same religious faith, it appears to the Commission that it is quite possible for the celebration of ‚Eid‐El‐Kabir’ to take place in a manner which respects the relevant animal welfare rules.

Depending on the reports it receives concerning this year's celebration, the Commission will consider the question of opening the Article 169 of the EC Treaty procedure in the near future.

Question No 91 by José Valverde López (H−0016/98)

Subject: 'Vegetable oil' as a generic label

The use of the term 'vegetable oil' as a generic food label runs seriously counter to consumers' information rights and economic interests and to the right to health. Specific forms of labelling must be introduced to make it clear what type of 'vegetable oil or fat' is involved in each individual case; to fail to do so is to encourage fraud and disinformation.

What initiatives is the Commission preparing to put an end to the extremely negative effect of this aspect of EC legislation on consumers' rights?

Answer

As the Commission explained in its answer to the Member's written question No 1609/97, the use of the term ‚vegetable oil’ in the list of ingredients of a food containing this type of ingredient complies with the Community legislation in force. In fact, paragraph 5(b) of Article 6 of Directive 79/112/EEC relating to the labelling of foodstuffs, states that ingredients in one of the categories listed in Annex I to the directive may be described in lists of ingredients using the name of the category only. Annex I states that refined oils other than olive oil may be described as ‚oils’ together with either the adjective ‚vegetable’ or an indication of specific vegetable origin. The same rule is applicable to refined fats. A similar provision is found in the ‚labelling’ standard of the codex alimentarius, at international level. It is of course understood that when oils or fats are sold as such, they must be labelled to indicate their specific origin.

The Commission has not been advised to date of any economic difficulties arising from the implementation of this rule, which has been established for twenty years. The terms ‚vegetable oils’ or ‚vegetable fats’ provide objective information and are therefore unlikely to mislead consumers with regard to the characteristics of a product. Economic operators can always enhance the information on the ingredients used by specifying the type of vegetable oil.

As far as health problems are concerned, the Commission is at present examining the need to amend Directive 79/112/EEC in order to improve the information provided for people suffering from food allergies or intolerance. The preparation of a list of foods or ingredients scientifically recognized to cause allergies, which should be included without fail in lists of ingredients if contained in a food (soya, peanut, walnut, etc.), is envisaged.

According to the information available to the Commission, it would seem, however, that only unrefined oils produced from such foods are likely to cause allergic reactions.

Question No 92 by Gunilla Carlsson (H−0025/98)

Subject: Guidelines for Commission officials

On 5 November 1997, the European Ombudsman gave his decision on the complaint regarding Commissioner Liikanen's letter to Director‐General Magnus Lemmel. In that decision, the Ombudsman draws attention to the need for the Commission to draw up guidelines concerning the possibilities officials have for establishing a reasonable balance between their scope for expressing opinions during the exercise of their duties and their fundamental right of free speech as provided for by the European Convention on Human Rights.
In view of this, will the Commission state whether it intends to draw up such guidelines and, if it does, when it will present them?

Answer

During 1997, the Commission undertook some reforms to reinforce and modernize its administrative and financial management. Within that context, the Commission is at present working on the preparation of a Code of Conduct for European Commission officials in their relationship with the public. A non‐definitive version of the draft Code of Conduct has in fact been forwarded to the European Ombudsman within the framework of an informal consultation.

Further to the recommendations addressed to the Commission by the Ombudsman that it should publish guidelines on the freedom of speech of officials, which should strike a balance between their freedom of speech and the duties and responsibilities resulting from their Staff Regulations, the Commission has become aware of the need to clarify this concept. The current exercise will provide an excellent opportunity to respond to the Ombudsman's expectations.

Question No 93 by Jaime Valdivielso de Cué (H−0027/98)

Subject: New accounting rules

In view of the announcement that the Commission is considering introducing new accounting rules, can it state if the new rules will only concern enterprises receiving state aid or if they will also cover private undertakings whose activities are protected by or act a under a monopoly or oligopoly?

Will the new rules have the effect of making the legislation applying to public enterprises far more demanding than that applying to the private sector, or will a balance be maintained in respect of the criteria required?

Answer

The Commission is working on an amendment to Directive 80/723/EEC on the transparency of financial relations between Member States and public undertakings. The amendment will establish cost accounting, that is, the separation of the accounts, of undertakings which, on the one hand, have special or exclusive rights or which receive financial support for the provision of ‚services in the general economic interest’ and which also carry out normal competitive activities. The new system will be applicable to private and public undertakings without distinction. The directive does not relate to the harmonization of accounting rules.

An instrument of this nature is needed as a result of the growing number of complaints relating to cross‐subsidization within undertakings of this type. The information provided by cost accounting will make it possible to guarantee fair competition and may also be used to justify the existence of special rights and compensatory payments, and consequently, to ensure compliance with public service requirements, which is in the Member States' interests.

The Commission is in fact preparing an amendment to the fourth Company Law Directive (Directive 78/660/EEC). The amendment will relate mainly to the valuation principles contained in the directive. It will not affect the scope of the directive itself, which is exclusively based on the legal forms of undertakings. The directive is applicable in the same way to all companies organized as corporate enterprises.

The changes it introduces will apply similarly to any undertaking covered by the directive, irrespective of whether the company's capital must be owned by private or public shareholders, whether the undertaking receives government subsidies or whether its market share is significant or marginal.

The Commission does not intend, at this stage of the preparation of the amendments in question, to introduce specific rules relating to public undertakings. The consultations it has carried out to date do not reveal any need to introduce such distinctions. Having said that, it is obvious that the Commission will continue to endeavour to ensure that the directives are correctly implemented in all Member States and thus to improve the transparency and comparability of company accounts.

Question No 94 by Per Gahrton (H−0034/98)

Subject: Sweden's derogations on feeding stuff additives

A number of derogations granted to Sweden concerning feeding stuff additives expired at the end of 1997. Sweden has been forced to lift some of its bans, e.g. on synthetic carotenoids and formic acid. Why does the Commission not consider such bans appropriate? Several other bans remain only because the Commission's committee has not been able to consider them yet. Does the Commission also intend to force Sweden to lift its bans on aflatoxins, ratoxins, copper, lead, PCB and phosphorus? The ban on meat‐and‐bone meal will be tightened up on 1 April. Does the Commission intend to propose banning MBM throughout the EU? Or will Sweden be forced to fall into line with the EU on this matter, too? Can the Commission name any instance in which it has brought or intends to bring its rules into line with Swedish environmental or health rules?

Answer

On joining the European Community, Sweden did in fact obtain several derogations relating to the implementation of Community legislation on animal nutrition, some of which expired on 31 December 1997.

Between August and December 1997, Sweden very belatedly supplied the detailed scientific evidence to justify its requests for the amendment of Community legislation. If Sweden has had induced to drop some of its requests, particularly with regard to carotinoids and xanthophylls, it is because it does not have the required scientific basis to justify such bans.

The Commission intends to re‐evaluate specific provisions of Community legislation in the light of the Swedish information as soon as possible. On 26 and 27 January, the Standing Committee on Feeding Stuffs examined some possible ways of adapting the present legislation, for example, by making it compulsory to show the phosphorus content of compound Feeding stuffs for fish, which until now was optional. Breeders would thus have better information on the phosphorus content of Feeding stuffs and could help to limit environmental emissions.

The Member will however understand that the Commission cannot approve requests for amendments to Community legislation unless they are based on adequate scientific data.

With regard to meat meals, the Commission has not asked Sweden to withdraw its national measures. In fact, the Commission is awaiting the results of the wider consultation it has initiated with regard to a possible general ban on meat meals, before suggesting guidelines.

Question No 95 by Alexandros Alavanos (H−0036/98)

Subject: Permanent Monitoring Body for air accidents

On 17 December 1997, a Ukrainian passenger aircraft, a Yakolev, crashed in western Macedonia, killing all the passengers and the crew. The investigation into the accident was undertaken by the Special Committee of the Greek Civil Aviation Service. On the basis of Council Directive 94/56/EC(20) , Member States are obliged to set up a Permanent Civil Aviation Monitoring Body which should be operationally independent of the national airport authorities with the task of investigating air accidents and formulating recommendations regarding safety. The Member States are required to comply with the Directive by 21 November 1996. Will the Commission say whether a Permanent Body has been set up in Greece, and if not why the Commission services have failed to monitor implementation of Directive 94/56/EC and what initiatives they will take to ensure that it is implemented forthwith?

Answer

The existing Accident Investigation Section in Greece is part of the Hellenic Civil Aviation Authority and does not, therefore, comply with the provision of Directive 94/56 which requires the investigation to be carried out by a permanent body, independent from the regulatory authority.

In May 1997, the Commission wrote to the Greek Government, in accordance with the procedure laid down in Article 169 of the EC Treaty, requesting that it submit its observations on the assumed infringements of the provisions of the Treaty.

In its reply, the Greek Government provided the Commission with the draft of a Presidential Decree which, when implemented, would resolve this issue. The Commission is following the progress of the procedure leading to the adoption of the Decree and will take further action if that progress is not satisfactory.

Question No 96 by Alfred Lomas (H−0037/98)

Subject: EU regulations applying to medical treatment in EU countries

Will the Commission confirm the legislation relating to medical treatment for EU nationals. If a French national woman, married to a British national man and dependent on her husband's national insurance contributions, seeks medical treatment in France, does she need to obtain Form E112?

Answer

Regulation 1408/71 on the coordination of social security schemes offers significant protection to Community workers and members of their families, especially in cases when they reside outside the Member State where they are insured, in cases of temporary stay out of this Member State and when – as in the case under consideration – they move to another Member State for treatment.

In the present case, although the person concerned is a French national, she is a member of the family of a person insured in the UK, and it is therefore the UK sickness insurance institution which is competent.

Article 22(1)(c) of Regulation 1408/71 provides that persons insured in one Member State have a right to move to another Member State to undergo treatment only if they have received prior authorization from their sickness insurance institution. The E112 form testifies that the person is entitled to receive the said benefits and states the period for which the authorization is given. The institution to which the form is addressed has, upon presentation of the form, the duty to provide the health care concerned.

Normally it is up to the sickness insurance institution to decide whether or not it will give its approval. However, where the treatment in question is among the benefits provided for by the legislation of the Member State where the person is insured, but not available within the time normally necessary with regard to the person's state of health, the required permission may not be refused.

Therefore, in the case described by the Honourable Member, the person should obtain the E112 form before going to France to undergo medical treatment. She will then be reimbursed by the UK sickness insurance institution.

However, the Commission would also like to draw the attention of the Honourable Member to the fact that, in the Decker and Kohll cases, currently pending before the EC Court of Justice, the Court has been asked to determine whether the prior authorization rule is compatible with the Treaty provisions on the free movement of goods and services. The judgment is expected in the near future.

Question No 97 by Ilona Graenitz (H−0042/98)

Subject: Recognition of sign language in the Member States

Having regard to the EP resolution of 18 July 1988 (OJ C 187, p. 236), which called for official recognition of national sign languages in the Member States, and whereas the recognition of this non‐ethnic language minority is a fundamental and important measure for the maintenance of culture, for the quality of life and, above all, for training opportunities for deaf people, I should like to know:

In which Member States has the national sign language actually been officially recognized or have comparable measures been taken?

Are those countries where this has still not occurred being supported in their efforts and, if so, in what way?

Is the Commission aware that, in the case of the deaf, this not only involves an issue affecting the 'disabled' but that what is involved here is a linguistic minority which is still not recognized in many Member States 10 years after the EP resolution?

Is the Commission planning to submit to the Council urgently required proposals on this issue?

Answer

In 1997, the Commission supported a far‐reaching research project carried out by Bristol University (UK). The purpose of this research was to draw a precise picture of the use of sign languages in the Community and to determine the comparative status of sign language in the different Member States.

The study highlighted the fact that sign languages can achieve official status in different ways and that there are major variations between Member States in terms of their experience and provision of sign language.

Sign languages in the Member States of Northern Europe appear to receive greater political and social recognition than in Southern Europe, resulting in better awareness of deafness and better provision of services to hearing‐impaired people.

A copy of the full report has been sent to the Honourable Member.

In line with its overall disability strategy, which recognizes that primary responsibility for action in this field rests with the Member States, the Commission endeavours to bring about the added value to be gained from cooperating at European level in terms of exchanging experience and transferring know‐how.

The Commission therefore supports a broad range of activities advancing the interests of deaf people, in particular through its support of the European Union of the Deaf.

However, the Commission has no plans at the moment to present specific proposals on the issue to the Council.

Question No 98 by Esko Seppänen (H−0045/98)

Subject: Double taxation and freedom of movement

Finnish nationals working in Sweden have paid their taxes to Sweden and receive their pensions from the Swedish state. They also pay tax on their pensions to Sweden. If a Finn who has worked in Sweden moves to Finland, he also pays tax on his pension in Finland. The tax paid in Sweden may be deducted from the tax payable in Finland, but the right of deduction does not apply to charges similar to taxes (veronluonteiset maksut). The persons concerned are thus partly subject to double taxation. Double taxation restricts the freedom of movement between these two Member States.

What does the Commission propose to do to guarantee freedom of movement?

Answer

The Commission has been informed of tax problems which Finnish residents, who have worked in Sweden, face with respect to Swedish pensions. The Commission has been made aware that legislative changes have recently been made to the applicable rules, and the Finnish authorities have been asked for information.

Whilst waiting for that information, the following general observations can be made:

In the absence of any fiscal harmonization in the field of personal income taxation, the national rules apply; these must, however, respect the Treaty, in particular the four freedoms and the non‐discrimination principle.
Double taxation of income is avoided by the double taxation conventions which provide for either imputation (of foreign paid tax from national tax due) or exemption from tax in one of the Member States concerned. In the latter case, the exempted income may, however, be taken into account in order to determine the applicable tax rate for the overall income (so‐called progressivity clause), which can result in a higher tax, in line with the principle of contributive capacity.

As regards taxes not covered by a double taxation convention, the Commission would like to ask the Honourable Member to indicate in more detail which kind of taxes he means.

Conflicts as to the competence of which Member State is entitled to levy social contributions are governed by Community law. A precise indication of levies causing problems would, however, be necessary to allow the Commission to look into the cases which the Honourable Member has in mind.

Question No 99 by Alan Donnelly (H−0047/98)

Subject: Conference on maritime education and training at Expo 98

The theme of EXPO 98 is 'The Ocean – A Heritage of the Future' and will provide a major opportunity for European maritime activities to emphasize their ongoing commitment to this sector and highlight the application of high technology and quality standards. This statement must, of course, be supported by the European Commission and the European Parliament, capitalizing on the forward looking policy initiatives taken in recent years.

An important element in this initiative is to ensure that the necessary skills and experience are available in the future by recruiting, educating and training the people involved in these activities. As part of its input to EXPO 98, is the European Commission going to organize a Conference on Maritime Education and Training in Lisbon?

Answer

The Community pavilion at EXPO '98 will include a Commission presentation of Community policies and initiatives linked to the theme of the exhibition, ’The Ocean – A Heritage of the Future’. The European Action Plan for the Information Society (including the MARIS project) and maritime Research and Technological Development will, for example, figure prominently.

The Commission will also organize a Conference on Europe and Quality Shipping, the purpose of which is to discuss with all shipping industries and services what commitments they are prepared to take without delay to encourage a more safety‐minded culture in shipping. Maritime Education and Training systems are very important to ensure high levels of maritime safety and environmental protection, as well as improvements in the living and working conditions of seafarers, and these subjects will naturally continue to have particular attention.

In December 1996, the Commission and the Irish Presidency organized the Dublin Conference on seafarers training and employment and since then the Commission has proposed amendments to Council Directive 94/58/EC on the minimum level of training of seafarers in order to comply with the new requirements of the 1995 Convention on Seafarer Training, Certification and Watchkeeping (STCW). Furthermore, the Commission is preparing a report on the Maritime Education and Training systems in the Member States and will publish that in due course.

These actions will help to improve the qualifications of seafarers and will certainly have an impact on the sector's employment.

In addition, the Commission is giving consideration to contributing to a conference in September on the Community's actions on maritime vocational training which would consider how vocational training should be developed to meet the needs of the maritime sector in the future, taking into account adaptation to new technologies.

The Commission is currently working with the relevant European associations in order to make provisional arrangements for such a conference.

Question No 100 by Brian Crowley (H−0050/98)

Subject: Norwegian herring

Herring fishermen in Ireland are being offered particularly low prices for the fish which they land this season partly at least because of the 23 000 tonne allowance for herring imports from Norway and also because of the preferential tariffs which the Norwegians enjoy in the Polish market by comparison with Irish fishermen.

Has the Commission undertaken an assessment of the economic impact of these factors affecting the market for herring, particularly in so far as they affect the income of fishermen along the south west coast of Ireland? Will the Commission now take steps to reduce the quantity of Norwegian herring given access to the European Union market and also seek access for European Union herring to the Polish market on the same terms as those available to Norway?

Answer

More than 70 % of chilled and frozen herring imported in the Community from third countries in 1995 was imported duty free. In addition to this, in 1996 and 1997, an autonomous tariff quota of 40 000 tonnes and of 23 000 tonnes, respectively, were opened as a consequence of the herring quota shortage in the North Sea.

Most of the EC herring imports originate in Norway and this country currently benefits from the various ‚ erga omnes’ tariff concessions given by the Community, including the 23, 000 tonnes mentioned in the Honourable Member's question, although not all this volume of fish has necessarily been imported from Norway.

The present tariff situation in the Community regarding herring is as follows:

Between 1 January and 14 February the MFN rate of duty of 15 % is applicable.

Between 15 February and 15 June imports are duty free.

Between 16 June and 31 December the MFN rate of duty is reintroduced, but:
a GATT quota of 34, 000 tonnes at 0 % rate of duty is opened;
a tariff quota of 800 tonnes in favour of Norway is opened;
imports of herring originating in the Faeroe Islands are duty free;
in 1996 and 1997 the already mentioned autonomous tariff quotas for herring have been opened.

According to the statistical series of prices for landings of herring in Killybegs and Rossaveal available to the Commission (01.01.96/01.08.97), no correlation can be established between the level of prices and the level of duties.

According to the Commission statistical data base, no imports of fresh, chilled or frozen herring have been made in Ireland in 1996 and 1997, whether from Norway or from any other origin.

Given the circumstances, the Commission cannot share the view that low prices in Ireland are due to the 23, 000 tonnes autonomous tariff quota opened in 1997. On the other hand, it may be that prices in Ireland are influenced more by export possibilities than by imports.

It is true that the Norwegians enjoy preferential tariffs in the Polish market, while the Community exporters have to pay the full rate of duty. But it is also true that Polish herring does not benefit from any preference in the EC market, apart from those that are given on an ‚ erga omnes’ basis. As regards Norwegian herring imported in the Community, it is not possible for the Community to go back on international agreements already concluded either bilaterally, such as that with Norway, or multilaterally, such as the GATT tariff quota.

Furthermore, the Commission, together with the Member States of the Community, has maintained regular contacts with the Polish authorities, in view of the negotiation of a fisheries agreement and reciprocal tariff concessions. Unfortunately, up to now, these contacts have not yielded any results.

The Commission does not foresee any tariff reduction for fishery products originating in Poland, as it does not foresee any tariff concession from Poland in the short term. In the medium term, this possibility could be envisaged, depending on the evolution of the negotiations for a fisheries agreement.

In view of the current market situation and the increase in the herring quotas available to the Community in 1998, the Commission does not intend to propose that the Community open an autonomous tariff quota for herring this year.

Question No 101 by Anita Pollack (H−0051/98)

Subject: Nepali – speaking refugees from Bhutan

Following Parliament's resolution of 14 March 1996, can the Commission report on its implementation of this resolution and its assessment of the current situation as concerns finding a solution to the refugee problem?

Answer

The recommendations contained in the EP resolution of 14 March 1996 are followed up and implemented as much as possible, provided that they are in the area of the Commission's competence. In this respect, the Commission

(i) maintains a continuous dialogue with the governments of Bhutan and Nepal to convince them to reach an agreement;

(ii) since 1992 provides, as the most important donor, assistance to the refugees in eastern Nepal: between 1992 and 1997 about ECU 13.5 million have been allocated for ‚care and maintenance’, plus relevant assistance occasionally provided for humanitarian support and food aid.

(iii) has made it clear to both governments that, conditional to a political solution, it is prepared to help them in the repatriation and resettlement process of the refugees, both those who will be selected for returning to Bhutan and those who will possibly remain in Nepal.

The Commission is, however, conscious that there is not an easy solution to that problem, especially when, mindful of the Sikkim political disappearance, the evidence is accepted that Bhutan is fighting a battle to preserve its unique identity. This was the important message delivered to the EP Delegation for South Asia and SAARC (South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation), when they visited Bhutan and Nepal in November 1997.

The Commission's assessment of the current situation is that a durable solution can come only from the two main parties' negotiations, which are hopefully ongoing. Unfortunately, the political instability and uncertainty which prevails in Nepal does not facilitate a quick solution of the problem.

A mediating role has been refused by the Indian Government as well as by the EU, several Member States having expressed their reluctance to such role and considered the UNHCR in a better position for such purpose.

Question No 102 by Marianne Eriksson (H−0055/98)

Subject: Use of acrylamide in the Member States

In its resolution B4‐0833/97 of 23 October 1997, Parliament calls on the Commission to investigate the use of acrylamide, which is contained in the sealing compound, Rhoca‐GII, among other products, in the Member States. Parliament also urges the Commission to propose a total ban on the use of acrylamide where it constitutes a risk to human health or the environment or where alternatives exist.

What is the Commission's position on these proposals?

Does the Commission consider that there should be an investigation into whether the French chemicals company, Rhone‐Poulenc, has broken EU environment legislation in connection with the toxic waste scandal surrounding the building of the tunnel through Hallandsåsen in Sweden?

Answer

The Commission is following the development of the incident in Sweden where dangerous substances leached into the environment during construction of a railway tunnel. One of these substances was acrylamide, another substance mentioned is N‐methylol‐acrylamide. The Commission is, however, not aware of all the details since the incident is still the subject of investigation by the Swedish authorities.

According to Commission policy, restrictions on the marketing and use of dangerous substances should be based on risk assessments and analyses of costs and benefits. Acrylamide, one of the components of Rhoca‐Gil, has been given priority for risk assessment under the regulation on existing substances. As part of the risk assessment information on the use of acrylamide is gathered. This evaluation will also focus on the use of the substance as a grouting agent in tunnels, investigating local environment and workers protection issues. If the risk assessment concludes that the risk posed by acrylamide needs to be reduced a risk reduction strategy will be proposed.

Member States are responsible for ensuring that the Community legislation for the control of chemicals are followed by manufacturers, distributors and importers placing chemicals on the Community market.

The various directives applying to chemicals, specifically to acrylamide, have been transposed to national law. Sweden is currently investigating the incident in Hallandsasen and will clarify whether the applicable legislation has been respected.

If it is the case that existing legislation is not sufficient to protect health and the environment, the Swedish authorities could bring this to the attention of the Commission.

Question No 103 by Ulla Sandbæk (H−0057/98)

Subject: EU sponsored structural adjustment programmes

Between 1995 and 1999, ECU 1400 m is being made available by the EU under the Lomé Convention to ACP countries implementing structural adjustment programmes. Studies show that the benefit to women is questionable. For instance, in a 1995 report: 'Gender and Structural Adjustment in Tanzanian Agriculture', Ingrid Palmer showed how reform policies at the macrolevel make women in farm households work harder for less access to and control over resources. Following such studies, the EU Council of Development Ministers agreed a resolution on Integration Gender Issues in development Cooperation in December 1995.

What indicators from micro‐ and meso‐level are currently being used by the Commission in relation to structural adjustment policies, and how is the interdependence between women's and men's roles both in production and in reproduction and the maintenance of human resources being measures and integrated into structural adjustment policy formulation?

Answer

The EC Structural Adjustment Support Programmes are designed to reflect the commitment in Article 243 of the revised Lomé IV Convention ‚to ensure that adjustment is economically viable and socially and politically bearable. For example, in most countries budgetary support under the EC Structural Adjustment Facility is targeted to social sector related expenditures. Indicators typically used are the health and education sector shares in a government's budget. At the same time, in some countries such as Tanzania, complementary support for the recipient's education and/or health sector programmes is provided. In Tanzania the Commission is particularly aware of the need to improve female education indicators, such as female enrolment and study completion percentages.

Evidently there is a need to further refine the design of Adjustment Policies and support for them to take more specific account of gender and environmental dimensions, among others. Studies in this area are ongoing, including the study in Tanzania, which is being complemented by additional field research. However, the analysis of constraints to women's participation in economic development and the translation of the results of such analysis into operational policies and indicators is a complex process, and so far appropriate indicators at micro‐ and meso‐level have not yet been agreed.

As part of the above process leading to the better incorporation of the gender dimension in adjustment policies and support, and also in project design generally, a programme is under way in 13 ACP countries including Tanzania, to improve gender awareness among government policy‐makers, and project planning personnel, as well as EC Delegation staff. The development of gender dimension project indicators are part of the programme.

Question No 104 by Anne McIntosh (H−0060/98)

Subject: The Second EC Driving Licence Directive

Will the Commission reconsider the Driving Licence Directive and, in particular, the impact that its provisions will have on diabetic drivers and their right to drive 3.5‐7.5 tonne vehicles?

Does the Commission agree that the standards imposed under this Directive discriminate against diabetics, causing a great deal of personal distress?

Answer

In 1991 the Transport Ministers' Council adopted Directive 91/439/EEC on driving licences with the aim of facilitating the free movement of persons and of enhancing road safety. This Directive contained a harmonization of the conditions for issuing and renewing driving licences, including the ‚Minimum standards of physical and mental fitness for driving a power‐driven vehicle’.

These minimum standards make the provision that a driving licence may only be issued or renewed for drivers of lorries and buses (including small lorries and minibuses) who suffer from diabetes mellitus in very exceptional cases, where duly justified by authorized medical opinion and subject to regular medical check‐ups.

The relevant provision was based directly on advice from medical experts from across the Community.

Recognizing the impact that these provisions could have for certain licence holders, the Commission included a clause in its original proposal which would have permitted the retention of existing rights in many cases. That clause was rejected by the Transport Ministers' Council.

Further consideration was given to the subject at a meeting of the Committee of Governmental Driving Licence experts in April 1996 where the national experts on diabetes mellitus again held that there were no grounds for changing the provisions in the Directive.

It is clear that both medical experts and Member State governments believe that, on road safety grounds, the provision concerning diabetes should not be amended. In view of that, and although the Commission recognizes that the application of these provisions can cause personal distress, there are no current plans to reconsider the existing law.

However, the Commission will keep the situation under review in the light of scientific progress and advice of medical experts.

Question No 105 by Richard Howitt (H−0065/98)

Subject: Private sector – Peru

The RCP (Red Cientifica Peruana) is a Peruvian non‐profit organization which supplies access to Internet and promotes the exchange of information. In order to operate, RCP collaborates with Telefonica del Peru S.A. as this company has been given a monopoly in the provision of telephone services in the country by the Peruvian government. However, from the time that Telefonica de España took control of the Peruvian telephone company and Entelperu, RCP feels it started a series of activities which have been undermining its functioning. In February 1996, RCP presented its case against Telefonica before OSIPTEL and the latter, through resolution o55‐cco/97, 20 months later, recognized the RCP demands.

The Commission, in an earlier reply to a parliamentary question (E−3377/97), stated that it 'will support and encourage European firms or sectors to adopt codes of conduct on a voluntary basis but in all such cases the Commission will be asking that a monitoring system be an integral part of the package'. Could the Commission investigate this case and intervene on the basis of the fact that Telefonica is a European company affecting local non‐profit initiatives?

Answer

The dispute between the Red Cientifica Peruana (RCP) and Telefonica del Peru (TDP) was caused by delayed availability of telecommunications circuits for Internet access.

In fact, RCP's activity is that of an Internet service provider not only to the scientific community but also to private users and companies. The company had furthermore registered ‚Internet’ as a trademark and was condemned for this reason by INDECOPI (National Institute for the Defence of Competition and Intellectual Property) in Peru.

The dispute was referred to OSIPTEL (Supervisory Agency for Private Investment in Telecommunications) which, in the first instance ruled against TDP in the case to which the Member refers. A final decision is now awaited, further to Telefonica del Peru's appeal. It is therefore premature to consider that TDP has been adjudged.

There is no reason to envisage action on the basis of the GATS trade rules, which Peru has ratified. This is in fact a dispute within Peru's internal market between a service provider and a telecommunications company, which falls under the authority of the Peruvian organization OSIPTEL, which has furthermore adopted temporary protective measures in favour of RCP before pronouncing judgement on the merits of the case.

There is no specific code of conduct in the field of telecommunications; with the European Commission's support, a code of conduct on direct foreign investment is being prepared by the OECD, which the European Commission will help to implement after it is adopted.

The Commission is prepared to carry out a fuller investigation of this case, and if justified, appropriate contact could be made with Telefonica Internacional, the majority shareholder of Telefonica del Peru. But the publicity given to this ‚controversy’ on the Internet will, in itself, bring a considerable amount of pressure to bear on the companies involved to adopt attitudes in line with ethical rules.

Question No 106 by Karl Olsson (H−0068/98)

Subject: Dumping of oil in the Baltic Sea

Once again, oil dumped in the Baltic Sea has done great damage to bird life, notably on Gotland. Fortunately, this has led to an increasingly keen debate on the subject, and the King of Sweden visited the island a few days ago to inspect the extensive damage for himself.

In 1966, the Swedish government set up a committee of inquiry with the task of taking legal action against the dumping of oil from ships at sea. That committee now says that international law and international commitments make it difficult for Sweden itself to take action against dumping and points out that other European countries very rarely, if ever, take action in respect of ships at sea.

International cooperation is obviously the only solution to deal with this environmental problem which also causes animals enormous suffering. What measures will the Commission take to curb the dumping of oil at sea?

Question No 107 by Astrid Thors (H−0072/98)

Subject: Waste oil reception facilities at Baltic and Russian ports

According to Swedish newspaper reports, 12 000 long‐tailed ducks had to be shot on Gotland last year as they were badly oiled. The year before, 27 000 long‐tailed ducks were shot for the same reason. This enormous suffering inflicted on animals is due to the fact that ports in Russia, the Baltic Republics and Poland are not interested in building reception facilities for waste oil at their ports. Another problem, common to all countries around the Baltic, is that the cleaning of oil from ships' tanks is not included in port charges, and unprincipled skippers discharge waste oil straight into the Baltic to avoid having to pay for cleaning.

Is it true that the applicant countries around the Baltic and Russia are unwilling to build reception facilities for oil, and what is the Commission planning to do convince them of the need for such facilities?

What progress has been made with the plans to include the cleaning of oil from ships' tanks in port charges at national level and within Helcom?

Joint Answer

The Marpol 73/78 Convention, to which all Member States, the Baltic States, Poland and the Russian Federation are contracting parties, prohibits the discharge of oil or oily mixtures in the Baltic. In addition, Marpol contracting parties must provide adequate facilities for the reception of the residues.

Community legislation on port State control already requires Member States to secure compliance with the Marpol Convention. Since the Commission does not believe that to be sufficient to prohibit illegal discharges into the sea, the Commission has announced its intention to adopt a proposal on port reception facilities in its 1998 legislative programme. The purpose of that measure would be to make it mandatory for ports in the Community to have the necessary facilities for waste disposal, including oily waste, and it would also be mandatory for ships to discharge all their waste ashore before leaving these ports. The legislative proposal will also have the intention of ensuring the harmonization of the charging of costs for the disposal of ship‐generated waste.

With regard to the Baltic Sea, the Helsinki Commission (HELCOM) has tabled proposals for port reception facilities for shipgenerated waste, which largely follow the Commission's views. In order to allow the Community to take up its responsibilities as a contracting party to HELCOM, where the Commission provides support to all the activities related to the prevention and reduction of marine pollution, whether through accidental or illegal operational oil spills, the Commission will ask the Council for a negotiating mandate when discussing these measures at Ministerial level.

Question No 108 by Per Stenmarck (H−0069/98)

Subject: Procurement of the Commission's telephone system

The Commission has said it will initiate procurement procedures in respect of its telephone system, both for the framework contract for the Commission as a whole and for the Berlaymont Building.

How does it intend to ensure that those procurement procedures are based on fair competition, and when will they be launched?

Answer

The Commission ensures impartiality with regard to the procurement of goods and services for its internal operations, by implementing the directives on public contracts. Telephone systems are not an exception to the rule.

The contract with the present supplier has two expiry dates: the section relating to the maintenance and operation of installations already in operation will expire at the end of 2001, and the section relating to the equipment of new buildings will expire at the end of 1998.

For 1999 to 2001, the following measures are being or have been planned:

‐  analysing the best way of equipping the new buildings with telephones between the end of 1998 and the end of 2001, ensuring that their interconnection with the existing telephone network through open and public interfaces;

‐  preparing to present the open invitation to tender in the second half of 1998.

Independent consultancy companies and inter‐departmental cooperation will ensure that these procedures produce the best possible quality‐to‐price ratio.

At the moment, technology is developing towards multimedia networks, but the Commission will not be able to take advantage of this progress when replacing its equipment until the products have stabilized. In order to ensure that the multimedia networks are successful, the Commission is initiating the following actions:

‐  analysing the opportunity to unite the services responsible for the operational data transfer networks and voice transfer;

‐  defining the strategy to be followed for architecture by the end of 2001;

‐  preparing the specifications for the new architecture. The invitation to tender should appear at the beginning of 2001.

The same considerations apply to the Berlaymont building since the Commission has appointed the company BERLAYMONT 2000 SA to award the contract by means of the above invitation to tender.

Question No 114 by Pat Gallagher (H−0102/98)

Subject: Possible ban on the use of fishmeal

A European Commission consultation paper on meat and bonemeal appears to favour a ban on the use of fishmeal as animal feed.

Does not the Commission feel that such a ban should only be considered if there is compelling evidence that fishmeal poses a risk, and is the Commission aware of any such evidence? Does the Commission agree that the production of fishmeal and the associated development of fish farming confers substantial economic benefits to coastal communities and that a proposal to ban the use of fishmeal could have serious economic implications for many coastal communities?

Question No 115 by Alan Gillis (H−0109/98)

Subject: Fishmeal in ruminant feed

Although I understand the reasons behind the Commission's proposal to ban fishmeal in ruminant feed because it is an animal protein, it would appear that the underlying basis for such a ban is one couched in fear of another BSE crisis, although there are no scientific grounds for this.

It has on the contrary been scientifically proved that selective use of fishmeal increases fertility in dairy herds and reduces lamb mortality rates.

Is the Commission overreacting to consumer fears in the wake of the BSE scandal, and will it review its proposals for a ban as there is no scientific evidence that such feed presents a risk to bovine or other livestock?

Joint Answer

In November 1997 the Commission launched a Consultation Paper calling for further reflection on the future policy of the Community's feed legislation and including the question of a possible ban on the use of all animal protein in the feeding of ruminants, on the grounds that these animals are herbivorous and therefore do not need animal protein in their diet. The Commission is aware of the economic impact of such a measure, in particular for the fishing industry and for farming in Europe.

Moreover, the Commission has currently no evidence of health or welfare problems associated with the use of fishmeal. At any rate, the use of animal proteins in the feeding of ruminants raises questions, due to the fact that it represents a departure from natural ways of feedings, which perhaps could lead to favourable epidemiological conditions for the development of new pathogenic agents.

Besides, the Commission knows the high nutritive value of fishmeal as the best source of high‐quality protein, the amino acids methionine and lysine and various other beneficial components of the diet. The Commission also accepts that fishmeal can play an important nutritional role, particularly for high yielding animals. A complete, well‐balanced diet contributes to the animal welfare and to the physiological functioning of animal organisms.

The intention of the Consultation paper is to offer the possibility to governments, professional sectors, scientists, associations, farmers, individuals etc. to comment on the present situation and the possible consequences of adopting different approaches. The Commission is now examining all information and comments that have been submitted and will publish its conclusion in the near future.

Question No 116 by Gerard Collins (H−0103/98)

Subject: Gas pipeline to Ennis and Shannon

Last September, the Irish Government submitted a proposal to extend the Irish natural gas network to a number of towns, including Ennis and Shannon, to the Commission's Competition Directorate in order to allow a full assessment of the state aids aspects of this proposal to be reviewed by the Commission.

Can the Commission now indicate if it has had the opportunity to undertake this assessment and, if so, can it now give its approval to this important proposal? If not, can the Commission give priority to completing its work with a view to an early decision on this matter?

Answer

The question raised by the honourable Member relates to the Commission's examination of a notified individual aid proposal concerning the extension of the Irish natural gas network.

According to Article 93(3) of the EC Treaty, the Commission examines if a notified aid proposal is compatible with the common market, and the Member State concerned may not put its proposed measures into effect until this procedure has resulted in a final decision.

Until now, the Commission has not yet been able to give its approval to the aid proposal as substantial information was missing. Nevertheless, the case is of high priority and it is the Commission's intention to complete its work with an early decision.

Question No 117 by Alex Smith (H−0105/98)

Subject: Proposal for changes to the common market in bananas

Under the proposal for changes to the common organization of the market in bananas, the Commission has proposed to allocate a global quota to ACP States rather than specify individual country quotas.

Could the Commission indicate why it does not want to allocate specific country quotas which, after all, is a simple administrative decision which does not run counter to WTO rules?

Furthermore, can the Commission justify not allocating individual country quotas – for reasons of administrative convenience – when the allocation of specific quotas would more effectively guarantee and ensure market access for the smaller ACP producers, an objective to which the EU has committed itself under the Convention of Lomé?

Answer

The WTO's Appellate Body ruling on bananas stated that the part of Article XIII of the GATT relating to the allocation of quotas between supplying countries must be respected, as the Community's waiver in respect of its Lomé Convention commitments does not cover this. In order to comply with the WTO ruling, the Commission has proposed that the WTO‐bound tariff quota, the autonomous tariff quota and the traditional ACP quantity should all be allocated using the same criterion, that of granting specific country allocations to ‚substantial suppliers’ which by convention is those countries supplying at least 10 % of imports.

The only countries which meet this criterion appear to be Ecuador, Costa Rica, Colombia and Panama, and therefore these are the only countries which would be given individual allocations using this criterion.

Even with total allocation to all suppliers, in accordance with the relevant provisions of Article XIII, it would not be possible to maintain the current levels of all the individual allocations to traditional ACP countries.

In the Commission's view, the current proposal, which maintains the same overall level of access for traditional ACP bananas, represents the best way of bringing the arrangements for the import of bananas into conformity with the WTO.

The Commission's proposal respects both obligations under the Lomé Convention and under the WTO agreements.

Question No 122 by Carlos Carnero González (H−0117/98)

Question No 123 by Laura González Álvarez (H−0118/98)

Subject: Commission appeal before the WTO against the US Helms‐Burton Act

Can the Commission say what steps have been taken to date and what its strategy will be with a view to complying with Parliament's resolutions?

Joint Answer

As part of the Understanding reached on 11 April 1997 between the Community and the US on the Helms‐Burton Act and the D'Amato Act the Community agreed to suspend the WTO Panel procedures which it had brought against the Helms‐Burton Act. It is correct that the Panel proceedings may rest ‚suspended’ for a maximum of 12 months, following which the Panel lapses. But after that period the Community may always open new proceedings by initiating new consultations. In the Understanding of April 1997, and in its bilateral contacts with the US, the Commission has always reserved the rights of the Community to resume the Panel procedure, or begin new proceedings, if action is taken against Community companies under either the Helms‐Burton Act or the D'Amato Act or if waivers are not granted.

Question No 124 by Edgar Schiedermeier (H−0111/98)

Subject: Call for tenders in connection with the Leonardo Da Vinci Programme (OJ C 372, 9.12.1997, p. 23)

Does the Commission believe that, with this call for tenders, it is fulfilling its obligations with regard to proximity to the citizen, transparency, concentration and efficiency, or does it feel that this more than obscure call for tenders may be compensated by the information days recently held, does it share my concern that such information events principally benefit a small and especially privileged clientele, and does it feel that, by restricting the call for tenders to two official languages, it has guaranteed equal opportunities for all participants?

Answer

1.  The call for tenders for 1998 (DG XXII/37/97) for the Leonardo da Vinci programme was published in the Official Journal of 17 December 1997 (OJ C 327/23) in the eleven official languages of the European Union, in accordance with the rules of publication in the Official Journal.

2.  The aim of the information days organized by the Commission in Brussels on 19 and 20 January 1998 was not to replace the call for tender but to help future promoters to establish partnerships and to fully understand the priorities and guidelines of the call for tenders published in the OJ. During the information days, over 1 130 participants, from 25 European countries, were able to obtain all the official documentation relating to the call for tender (vademecum, application forms, decision) in the eleven Community languages. They were also able to have individual meetings, in their own languages, with representatives of their national coordinating organizations, the Commission, or the technical assistance office. Furthermore, the national bodies coordinating the programme are organizing information seminars in their own countries and languages, open to all interested future promoters, to help them to prepare their bids. It is therefore wrong to say that this programme will only benefit a small and privileged clientele.

3.  For budgetary and practical reasons, the thematic and practical workshops during the information days were organized in two languages only (English and French). The decision to use two languages was therefore made, with regard to the workshops only, for budgetary and practical reasons, to encourage interactivity and the formation of partnerships.

4.  The Commission therefore considers that it has done as much as it can within the framework of its budgetary resources to guarantee equal opportunities for all participants.

Question No 125 by Birgitta Ahlqvist (H−0119/98)

Subject: Directive 90/667/EEC on the burial of animal carcases

The burial of animal carcases is prohibited pursuant to Directive 90/667/EEC(22) , although some derogations have been granted. Since 1986, Sweden has had a very good animal welfare and food safety record; for instance, food is practically salmonella‐free, meat‐and‐bone meal has not been used since 1996, and the consumption of antibiotics has fallen by 30 % since 1986.

A derogation from the ban on burying animal carcases was initially granted for certain parts of Norrland owing to the absence of high‐risk waste and because the transport of animal carcases poses practical problems in sparsely populated rural areas.

What would the Commission's views be on extending this derogation to the whole of Norrland?

Answer

Directive 90/667/EEC laying down the veterinary rules for the disposal and processing of animal waste, allows the burial of animal carcases under certain circumstances.

In particular, the competent authorities of the Member State may decide that these carcases may be disposed of by burial where they originate from places with difficulties of access and/or the quantity and the distance to be covered does not justify collecting the waste.

The same directive also establishes rules for burial in order to prevent any spread of disease and any contamination of water tables or other environmental nuisance.

It is, therefore, up to the Swedish authorities to assess whether or not the burial of carcases may be allowed in Norrland.

Question No 126 by Lone Dybkjær (H−0121/98)

Subject: Commission answer to a question concerning the comprehensibility of a Directive

The Commission's answer to question No 56 (H−0860/97)(23) , in which I criticized its proposal amending European Parliament and Council Directive 95/2/EC(24) for being incomprehensible, was that it did not share my opinion that the proposal was incomprehensible but would be pleased to answer any technical questions that I might have about the proposal.
