Answer

The Commission regrets that the honourable Member finds the Commission proposal amending European Parliament and Council Directive 95/2/EC(25) on food additives incomprehensible for non‐experts, e.g. the public. Directives on food additives need to be very detailed and technical in order to be precise and clear enough for the industry to apply the rules correctly. This is necessary when protecting public health and especially in this specific case.

However, as the honourable Member is aware, directives are to be implemented into national legislation, as in the case for all directives concerning food additives. Therefore, it is left to the Member States to determine how the obligations imposed by the directive are to be presented in the national legislative implementing measures.

Finally, the institutions, including the Commission, have agreed to adopt measures with regard to the quality of drafting of Community legislation(26) . The Commission has devoted a large part of its ‚Guidelines for legislative policy’ which it adopted in 1996, to the quality of drafting. In 1997, the ‚Legislative technique rules’ were up‐dated in order to guide Commission departments during the drafting of legislative proposals and other legal documents.

Question No 127 by Mirja Ryynänen (H−0123/98)

Subject: Green Paper on libraries and the information society

Public libraries across the EU are calling on the European Commission to stop putting off launching the debate on their future in the information society originally promised for last year.

A public debate on how the Union should tackle issues such as the preservation of work, privacy, copyright liability and universal access to information is vital as the online age begins to challenge the traditional role of public libraries.

What are the Commission's intentions and when will the Green Paper on the role of libraries in the information society be forwarded to the European Parliament?

Answer

Since the European Parliament requested the Commission in March 1997 to prepare a Green Paper on the Role of Libraries in the Information Society, a great deal of preparatory work has been undertaken in researching the evolution of public library services in the Member States. This has revealed a number of significant developments at national level indicating the importance most Member States now give to the provision of access to electronic information and support services through public library networks.

The preparatory work, which has been carried out in consultation with the relevant organizations in the Member States, seems to indicate that there is wide agreement on the need for generalized access to new information services which will help to avoid the development of a two‐tier division of users. In this context, public libraries will certainly have an important role to play.

The Commission agrees that items such as preservation, privacy, copyright and universal access need attention. Some of these are being addressed in other initiatives relating to the information society, for example in connection with work on convergence, on the safe use of the Internet and on the need for international cooperation on electronic commerce. They are also the subject of a number of legislative measures such as the existing Directive on the protection of personal data or the proposed Directive on Copyright and neighbouring rights in the Information Society. The Commission is now in a better position to examine matters that would relate more specifically to the role of libraries in the information society and hopes to complete this work possibly before the summer break.

Notwithstanding the above, the Commission's current Telematics Programme actively supports R & D projects aimed at preparing and strengthening Europe's public library networks for the information society. These efforts are likely to be reinforced under the Fifth Framework Programme.

Question No 128 by Ioannis Theonas (H−0124/98)

Subject: Abolition of collective bargaining on public sector staff regulations in Greece

The Greek Government has submitted to the Greek Parliament a draft law aiming to abolish collective bargaining over staff regulations in public enterprises – stock market‐listed or not – and government‐subsidized companies. The regulations will in future be laid down by law, which has provoked a huge outcry from the workers involved.

In the Commission's view, is this action contrary to the social policy embodied in the protocol to the Treaties, to social legislation and the Social Charter, and to ILO Convention 98 in that it is a flagrant violation of fundamental social and trade union rights, abolishes basic forms of trade union activity and flouts any notion of industrial relations and dialogue? What measures will the Commission take to safeguard these rights and satisfy the workers' just demands?

Answer

The situation described by the honourable Member of Parliament falls within the exclusive competence of the Member State concerned. There is no Community legislation on the conduct of collective bargaining at national level, and as long as the rights of workers laid down by Community law are respected, the Commission has no competence in the matter.

However, in fulfilling its obligation to promote and facilitate the social dialogue at Community‐level, the Commission has affirmed that the success of the European social dialogue depends on the existence of a healthy social dialogue at national level. This will be extremely important in implementing the decisions of the European Council on Employment and the Employment Guidelines.

As regards fundamental social rights in general, the Commission will be setting up an expert group consisting of independent experts which, following the report of the ‚Comité des Sages’, will reflect on fundamental social rights of workers in the Community.

Question No 129 by Christine Oddy (H−0126/98)

Subject: Jubilee 2000 campaign and debt cancellation

Is the Commission aware of the Jubilee 2000 Campaign which proposes cancellation of debts of the world's poorest countries by the year 2000?

What steps will the Commission take to assist this campaign?

Answer

The Commission shares the concerns of the Jubilee 2000 Campaign regarding debt problems of the poorest countries. It has been increasingly recognized that despite progress made during recent years in providing more generous debt relief measures and despite their efforts to implement economic reforms, a number of the poorest countries are still constrained by excessive external debt burdens.

It should be noted that the Community is primarily a donor of grant resources and a very small creditor in this context. Solutions to the debt problems of the poorest countries will require concerted action among all creditors in order to have the necessary impact. The Debt Initiative for the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (the HIPC Debt Initiative) which was launched in 1996, is a framework for such coordinated action. The aim of this initiative is to reduce the debt burdens of the heavily indebted poor countries to sustainable levels and thereby to support their efforts to implement economic reforms and to reduce poverty. The Commission strongly welcomes this initiative and although the Community is a very small creditor, it is politically very important that the Community participates and plays its part. It is encouraging that the Council has now confirmed the Community participation in this initiative with respect to Community claims on the heavily indebted poor countries.

The HIPC initiative is clearly in the spirit of the Jubilee 2000 campaign. It may be less far‐reaching, but is also more realistic, being based on an agreement by governments and multilateral creditors to take action in a concerted way to help those countries which make serious development efforts.

Question No 130 by Vassilis Ephremidis (H−0127/98)

Subject: Massive demonstrations by farmers in Greece

Greek farmers have held massive demonstrations all over Greece in recent days in an attempt to safeguard their incomes and their right to continue farming and in protest at the policy of penalizing their resistance which has led to the prosecution of 8000 farmers. Greek farmers are opposed to the Agenda 2000 guidelines and the adverse effects of cutbacks and the abolition of subsidies and other support measures, the constant squeezing of product quotas across the board, the simultaneous increase in the coresponsibility levies and the relentless onslaught against southern produce even before the forthcoming review of the CAP. Another key demand is for immediate measures to reduce production costs by cutting the cost of inputs, which are among the highest in Europe.

What measures will the Commission take to meet the demands of Greek farmers, taking account of the fact that the policy being pursued is resulting in the confiscation of property, ruin, unemployment, destitution and the productive and social marginalization of half of the farming families in Greece?

Answer

Agenda 2000 proposes improving the competitiveness of certain products by reducing price support and, on the other hand, increased direct payments. Greek farmers must have misunderstood the proposals when they establish a link to the actual management of market policy instruments such as quotas or levies. Agenda 2000 is presenting balanced proposals for reforming market policy in several sectors, taking into account the particular responsibilities of each sector.

Production costs will be reduced with the Agenda 2000 proposals on cereals in all those sectors which use cereals as feedstuff. Moreover, the cost of inputs in general underlay the development of the particular markets. The Commission has always worked on improving the functioning of the internal market. Administrative cutting of input costs does not fall under the Commission's competences.

High production costs may result also from structural handicaps. With its current and its future policy on supporting structural adjustment in agriculture, the Community is supporting the necessary adaptations. Within the current Objective 1 Community Support Framework a total amount of ECU 903 million financed by the EAGGF is devoted to Objective 5a measures in Greece. Moreover, farmers can benefit from other adjustments promoted by the accompanying measures (agri‐environmental, afforestation and early retirement schemes) which will be reinforced by Agenda 2000. The Agenda 2000 proposals, in particular the increase in direct payments, the reorganization of rural development policy and the continuation of the Structural Policy Objective 1 programmes will ensure a fair standard of living for the agricultural community and will provide alternative income opportunities in rural areas.

Question No 131 by Reinhard Rack (H−0130/98)

Subject: Assistance to regions bordering the CEECs

As a result of the accession of Spain and Portugal in 1986, the structurally weak southern regions of the Community faced serious problems of adjustment, which was why the Integrated Mediterranean Programmes were adopted. A similar problem now exists along the EU's external border with the CEECs, and this was the theme of a conference of representatives of the border regions (from Germany, Finland, Italy and Austria), which took place in Graz on 29 January 1998.

Does the Commission have a positive view of an integrated special programme to accompany the EU's enlargement to the east and of targeted priorities in the INTERREG programme for the border regions?

What other measures, such as those relating to competition law, does the Commission intend to take to support the process of adjustment in the structurally weak border regions?

Answer

The Commission fully comprehends the specific situation of the regions situated on the EU"s external borders with the CEECs. However, the Commission does not believe that enlargement towards such countries and the resulting opening of markets is necessarily a potential danger or threat to the economies of neighbouring regions inside the Community's present territories. Enlargement and the removal of the existing barriers to free movement at such borders will generate a very significant economic stimulus and will provide new prospects for development.

Furthermore, within the scope of the Structural Funds, the Community has been funding the Community initiative, INTERREG, since 1990, and is now funding INTERREG II relating to the development of border areas and cross‐border cooperation. Amongst other things, the aim of this initiative is to respond to the external border areas' new situation and to make the most of it. In fact, the regions along the present external borders between the EU and the CEECs are taking advantage of this initiative to develop their indigenous potential, use new opportunities resulting from the removal of the Iron Curtain and improve their economic competitiveness.

As well as some changes in the management of the Structural Funds, which will enable the Member States to take specific problems into consideration, the Commission has included a section relating to cross‐border cooperation in the Community initiative ‚Agenda 2000’, for 2000‐2006. The initiative will be an appropriate instrument for responding to the possible need for structural adaptation in the regions affected by enlargement. The Commission will ensure that the initiative is as flexible as it needs to be, and that it is used to ensure that the future enlargement of the Community is of real benefit to border regions, which will become regions with internal borders. On the other hand, the Commission has not planned any specific Community initiatives in favour of such regions, or any special instrument comparable to the integrated Mediterranean programmes of the 1980s.

Question No 134 by MaLou Lindholm (H−0162/98)

Subject: Rejection of application for funding of ECAD (European Cities Against Drugs)

Joint Answer

The European Union's action plan to combat drugs (1995‐99) constitutes the reference framework for activities conducted in this field by the EU and its Member States and has no bias in favour of a legalization approach towards illegal drugs.

Effective co‐ordination of the actions to be pursued and coherence of the approach are monitored by a specific co‐ordination unit of the General Secretariat of the Commission.

Question No 135 by Concepció Ferrer (H−0136/98)

Subject: Relations between the EU and Equatorial Guinea

On 21 January 1998 a number of still obscure events took place on the island of Bioko (Equatorial Guinea), which appear to have involved numerous members of the Bubi ethnic group being arrested and tortured, while the threat of the death penalty is hanging over four former Spanish ex‐legionaries of Equatorial Guinean origin arrested following those events. Answer

On 21 January, several military installations were attacked near the capital, Malabo, on the island of Bioko, and several soldiers and civilians were killed. The incident lead to a wave of arrests amongst the supporters of the Movement for Self‐Determination of the island of Bioko, a illegal movement of the Bubi ethnic population, which makes up the native population of Bioko. Question No 136 by Liam Hyland (H−0142/98)

Subject: The future of EU beef exports to SE Asia

In view of the recent serious economic problems that have arisen in this market, does the Commission now consider that it can maintain its optimism for EU beef exports to SE Asia, taking into account also the fact the cattle prices in Argentina and Australia are expected to remain substantially below EU prices?

Answer

The price reduction proposed in the beef reform included in Agenda 2000 should bring Community beef market prices closer to the prices of the other beef exporting countries in the world. This will be completed at the end of the transitional period provided for the introduction of this reform, i.e. in the year 2002. It should make it possible for part of Community exports to the traditional markets to take place without a refund, and to gain some new markets. The Commission still considers this as a realistic forecast.

Question No 137 by James Elles (H−0144/98)

Subject: Unpasteurized milk

Does the European Commission believe that unpasteurized milk presents a potential hazard to human health and should therefore be banned from sale in the Member States?

Answer

Direct consumption of unpasteurized milk has in the past been the cause of numerous cases of food poisoning, tuberculosis and brucellosis infection in humans.

The Commission is aware of the risks of the consumption of unpasteurized milk, which is why, in 1991, the Commission submitted a draft directive on health rules for the production and marketing of milk and milk‐based products which was adopted by the Council in 1992 (Directive 92/46). The directive establishes a number of specific health rules, which considerably reduce the health hazards of the consumption of unpasteurized milk. Although there is no such things as zero risk in this area, the Commission can, if necessary, reinforce the measures, by adopting further animal health and hygiene measures for the production of unpasteurized milk for human consumption. Pending the adoption of such conditions, Member States can maintain stricter conditions, including banning the sale of unpasteurized milk.

Within the framework of the simplification of the veterinary directives and their consolidation with the food hygiene directive requested by Parliament, the Commission will consider the best measures to adopt in order to ensure the lowest possible risk to public health.

Question No 138 by Roy Perry (H−0145/98)

Subject: Tobacco

The levels of tobacco tax are different in all the Member States of the European Union, with the highest being in the UK. This has resulted in a large amount of smuggling between the continent and the UK. How significant are the differing levels of tobacco tax in restricting the free movement of goods?

There is an increasing amount of tobacco smuggling within the European Union as a result of differing levels of tobacco tax, specifically the UK's high tax compared with Belgium's lower taxes. The sale of tobacco products by smugglers is not regulated, meaning that children have greater access to these products. To what extent is the European Union's objective of reducing tobacco consumption undermined by the sale of tobacco products to under‐age children by smugglers?

Answer

It is indeed true that the levels of taxes on tobacco products are different in the Member States. However, these differences in tax levels do not restrict the free movement of goods and thus are not a constraint on the functioning of the internal market.

Under the harmonized Community rules which have been in force since 1 January 1993, excise duty on tobacco products normally has to be paid in the Member State of consumption. For commercial movements this means that goods are normally moved from one Member State to another under suspension arrangements and it is only when they are released from such arrangements in the Member State of final consumption that duty becomes chargeable.

On the whole, it would appear that, as far as legitimate trade is concerned, this system operates relatively well despite the large differences in excise duty rates between Member States. The fact that tobacco products can be traded under suspension of duty means that rate differences do not lead to any significant distortion of choice or competition on the part of companies involved in trade at this level of the distribution chain.

As far as purchases by private individuals are concerned, under the principles of the internal market, tobacco products purchased for individuals' own use and transported by them from one Member State to another are subject to excise duty and VAT in the Member State in which they were acquired. Provided that the goods are indeed for their own use, there is no restriction at all on the freedom of individuals to carry out such purchases.

The smoking prevention efforts at the Member State and Community level are described in the Commission's Communication of 18 December 1996(27) , which has since been the subject of discussions in the Council, in the European Parliament(28) and in the Economic and Social Committee(29) .

A policy of increasing price tobacco products through fiscal and other measures is an important part of a smoking prevention strategy, and is particularly significant in dissuading young people from beginning or continuing to smoke. The issue of the relationship between smuggling and the need to reduce tobacco consumption was examined at a recent international seminar in Finland in January 1998, and this issue will be kept under review by the Commission.

Question No 139 by Karin Riis‐Jørgensen (H−0148/98)

Subject: Reinstatement of monopoly of telecommunications services

In Denmark, the telecommunications company Tele Danmark has launched the dual concept consisting of a fixed/mobile service which builds on the access network owned 100 % by Tele Danmark.
Tele Danmark has offered to be the service provider for competing mobile operators by proposing a similar solution to them. However, this solution involves charging and service terms that are not competitive, e.g. the onward connection costs are three times higher. Tele Danmark is marketing the dual concept as follows: 'If you have a mobile phone with a different operator than Tele Danmark Mobil, you must of course switch to us in order to enjoy all the benefits of Duet. We can also help you find the right new mobile number'.

To what extent does this reinstatement of the monopoly contravene the general principles of free competition enshrined in the Treaty of Rome and the Union?

Answer

Tele Danmark is a dominant undertaking in the sense of Article 86 EC as regards the provision of the fixed voice telephony service. It is therefore fully subject to the prohibitions of this Article as regards possible abuses of its dominant position. Tele Danmark is also subject to the provisions of EP and Council Directive 95/62/EC on the application of Open Network Provision to Voice Telephony.

A new converging service combining a fixed and mobile subscription and services appears to offer a number of advantages to customers, such as one telephone number for both services, one itemized bill, etc. However, where such services are introduced by dominant operators, the impact for competitors both on the fixed and mobile telephone markets would have to be assessed. In particular, the possibility of offering such services would have to be open to all fixed and mobile operators on a nondiscriminatory basis, and cross‐subsidies by the incumbent to its mobile operation would have to be excluded. The latter would in any event require complete transparency in their accounts, which under certain circumstances may only be possible if the mobile operation of the incumbent is a separate legal entity.

In any case, such issues are also of the competence of the National Regulatory Authorities and the National Competition Authorities and the Commission would in principle not take action as long as these Authorities are investigating possible recourses against the offer of such combined services.

In the specific case referred to by the Honourable Member, which appears to be the first of its kind but likely to be followed shortly in other Member States, the Commission will contact both the Danish Telecommunications Regulatory Authority and the Danish Competition Authority, and will investigate the details of the arrangements in the context of the competition rules, if necessary.

As a general measure, the Commission has launched a Community wide investigation into the interconnection charges between mobile and fixed operators; the findings will be relevant in the context of the newly emerging dual fixed/mobile services.

Question No 140 by Paul Rübig (H−0152/98)

Subject: Monitoring fees at sporting events

In Austria 'monitoring fees' have to be paid to the executive at such highly popular sporting events as ski races, cycle races and marathons open to the public. They impose a considerable financial burden on organizers of such events and on sports associations.

If these fees differ among the various EU countries, the choice of venue for sporting events is bound to be influenced.

Can the Commission say whether these monitoring fees differ among the EU Member States and if so, whether the resulting distortion of competition is compatible with the legislation of the EU internal market?

Answer

The Honourable Member Paul Rübig has asked a question concerning charges levied in connection with sporting events in Austria.

The Commission would like to point out that charges levied locally in connection with a single event are not subject of harmonization at Community level. The charge seems not to be taxation in the meaning of Article 95 of the EC Treaty, which prohibits fiscal discrimination of products form other Member States.

A fee collected by public authorities for the delivery of a certain service does not constitute state aid under Article 92(1) of the Treaty. On the contrary, state aid might be involved if a Member State grants services to certain undertakings without asking for an adequate remuneration.

In the light of the information provided by the Honourable Member the Commission can only conclude that a conflict with the existing Community fiscal and competition law is not apparent.

Question No 141 by Inger Schörling (H−0155/98)

Subject: Trade union rights

At the request of the European Council Summit Meeting in Amsterdam, the Commission has drawn up a proposal for a Council Regulation introducing an intervention mechanism for the Commission to remove certain obstacles to trade.

The aim is to secure freedom of movement for goods within the internal market, which is one of the Community's fundamental principles. So as to prevent infringements of the principle of freedom of movement, which may arise through requiring licences or technical certificates, stopping products by obstructing transport on motorways, at airports or ports, for instance, the Commission wishes to be able to intervene quickly and request Member States to take measures to remove the obstacles. Member States will have between three and five days to submit their views. If a Member State does not comply with the Commission's decisions, the Commission may take the matter further to the Court of Justice.

The EU has no jurisdiction in this area and the Regulation is proposed on the basis of Article 235.

Does the proposal imply that the Commission can force Member States to intervene in strikes and lockouts? The trade unions are highly critical of EU interference with fundamental trade union rights and intervention in trade union disputes. Does the proposal not jeopardize dialogue between the two sides of industry? How will the right to strike be guaranteed?

Answer

In adopting a proposal for a Council Regulation, introducing an intervention mechanism for the Commission to remove certain obstacles to trade, on 18 November 1997, the Commission intended to respond to the Amsterdam European Council's request as efficiently as possible, The proposed intervention mechanism does not affect any fundamental rights, such as the right to strike, nor does it interfere in social dialogue at national level. In fact, the existence and exercising of the right to strike is guaranteed under national laws and as such is not affected by Community law.

The Commission would like to emphasize that the aim of the proposal is to ensure that the Member States involved take the necessary, commensurate steps available within their own legal systems to quickly remove the serious obstacles observed by the Commission, thereby safeguarding the free movement of goods. In this respect, the Commission would like to remind the Member that in a judgment of 9 December 1997, the Court of Justice ruled that a Member State's failure to take action against individuals whose actions create barriers to trade is incompatible with Article 30 of the EC Treaty, pursuant to Article 5 of the EC Treaty.

Question No 142 by David Bowe (H−0156/98)

Subject: Mutual recognition for teachers in the European Union

On behalf of the National Union of Teachers in the UK and the Educational Institute of Scotland, Coopers and Lybrand recently produced a report entitled 'European Comparisons in Education Funding'. This report revealed that there is a considerable disparity between Member States as regards the career progression for teachers, despite the fact that there is seeming agreement on schoolteachers' initial pay and status.

Is the Commission concerned that such a disparity could effect mutual recognition of teachers' qualifications and experience and thus their ability to move freely around the EU?

Answer

The Commission is aware of the diverse features and modalities for career progression of teachers in the Member States. On behalf of the Commission, Eurydice has prepared several editions of ‚Key Data on Education’, which clearly documents this diversity. Key Data 1997 chapter G is fully dedicated to teachers. In order to implement the transparency principle concerning the different education systems, the Commission has produced a Green Paper on Mobility, in which the various obstacles hampering teachers mobility are pinpointed. An action plan indicating possible paths to overcome these obstacles will be presented.

The Commission respects, in accordance with Article 126 of the EC Treaty and in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, the complete responsibility of the Member States in this field. It is in the framework of this diversity that the Member States have the full competence and responsibility in modifying the conditions necessary for easing teachers' free movement around the Community. Hence, each Member State is entirely free to regulate a profession on its territory and to determine the level and the contents of studies required to gain access to the profession in question.

However, the national rules must respect the Community directives on the recognition of qualification. In the case of teachers, Directive 89/48/EEC on a general system for the recognition of higher education diplomas awarded on completion on education and training of at least three years' duration applies. Recognition obtained according to this directive confers upon the migrant the right to apply to teaching posts in the host Member State on the same conditions that apply to holders of national diplomas, i.e. with the same rights and the same obligations.

In absolute terms, teachers represent the largest single professional group to have benefited from this directive. According to the figures supplied by Member States towards the end of 1994, more than 5, 100 teachers have obtained recognition of their teaching qualifications in another Member States, but of these 3, 800 were recognized in the United Kingdom alone.

Question No 143 by Robert Evans (H−0160/98)

Subject: Education funding comparisons

Is the Commission aware of a recent report drawn up by Coopers and Lybrand, commissioned by the National Union of Teachers and the Educational Institute of Scotland which examined 'European Comparisons in Education Funding'?

One of the most important findings was that no country is entirely satisfied with their provision for children with special/additional educational needs. What is the Commission doing to aid the Member States in their search for better provision for these children?

Answer

The Commission has supported the action of the Member States since 1987 by implementing three Community programmes relating to the integration of disabled people, and their education in particular. The first programme and the programme HELIOS I contributed towards improving our understanding of the educational situation of disabled people in the Member States. In the programme HELIOS II (1993‐1996), 192 exchange activities divided into thirteen subject groups provided opportunities for cooperation and the publication of subject brochures describing the present situation along with recommendations to improve the conditions enabling disabled people to receive education. The final seminar, held in Luxembourg in November 1996, drew up a summary of the programme and led to the preparation of the ‚Luxembourg Charter’ which obtained a consensus of opinion on the principles, strategies and proposals of ‚school for all’.

In the Community programme on education, Socrates, and in two other programmes – Leonardo da Vinci (training) and Youth for Europe III (actions outside educational structures) – the principle of the European dimension in education recommends the integration of children, adolescents and adults with special needs in the spirit of all actions. In 1997, in a desire for transparency, the Commission supported the processing and distribution of information on a Web site in conjunction with the Europa‐Socrates host, carried out by the European Development Agency for the Education of People with Special Needs (launched by the Danish government in November 1996 and supported by all the Member States). The Commission is also supporting the revision of the report on the present situation of special or integrated educational systems in the Member States, which should be available this spring, and research in conjunction with the OECD on special education indicators, whose results will be published during 1998.

During this Presidency, the Commission is supporting a seminar on education for people with special needs (on 7 May in Windsor). However, responsibility for the implementation of any measure relating to the organization and content of educational systems falls within the competency of the Member States.

Question No 144 by Mihail Papayannakis (H−0984/97)

Subject: Plant protection products
Directives 91/414(30) and 90/642/EEC(31) prohibit the use of plant protection products where they might have undesirable effects on public health and the environment; they also require the Member States to take appropriate measures to control and review the marketing and use of such products.

According to Ministry of Agriculture agronomists and academics, government controls in Greece are piecemeal and inadequate, pesticide residues are above safety limits and there is insufficient consumer information.

Since recent European research shows that 5 % of cases of cancer are caused by the use of plant protection products, will the Commission say whether Greece has complied with the above Directives as amended, as it should have done for years, and what measures it will take to bring Greek legislation into line with Community law on these points?

Answer

Concerning controls on marketing and use of plant protection products, Directive 91/414/EEC provides that Member States have to make the necessary arrangements to check officially their placing on the market and use in accordance with the provisions of the directive. The Directive leaves however to each Member State to regulate the detailed organization of those controls, and to determine the intensity with which they are performed; it provides only that Member States send each year a report on the controls made.

In the preceding years Greece has satisfied this requirement. The Commission is considering, whether in the framework of a future amendment of Directive 91/414/EEC or otherwise a strengthening of the provisions concerning controls has to be provided.

With regard to the monitoring of pesticide residues in agricultural commodities, the Greek authorities have also submitted in recent years the report on their residue monitoring program, as required under Directive 90/642/EEC. The reports of the Member States are under examination by the Commission with a view to making recommendations for more effective monitoring in the forthcoming years.

The Commission considers that the amendments to Directive 90/642/EEC on the fixing of maximum levels for pesticide residues in and on certain products of plant origin, including fruit and vegetables(32) made by Directive 97/41/EC(33) , due to be implemented by the Member States by 31 December 1998, will provide a framework for increased effectiveness of the arrangement for inspection and monitoring of pesticide residues. The Commission intends to make detailed implementing rules necessary for the proper functioning of the amended provisions before that date.

The Commission can also indicate to the Honourable Member that it recently received from the European Environment Bureau a study ‚Pesticides and Cancer’. The Commission submitted this study for further consideration to the Scientific Committee for Plants.
